questions.text: The flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and extension at proximal and distal interphalangeal joints are actions of which of the following muscles of upper limb?
questions.solution:
Lumbrical muscles:

  • There are four lumbrical muscles and numbered first, second, third, and fourth from lateral to medial side.
  • They are small slender muscles one for each digit.
  • They are named lumbricals because of their elongated worm-like shape
  • 1st & 2nd are unipennate muscles.
  • 3rd & 4th are bipennate muscles.
  • Origin
    • Lumbricals 1 and 2: From lateral side of lateral two tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus.
    • Lumbricals 3 and 4: From adjacent sides of medial three tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus.
  • Insertion
    • The tendons cross the radial side of metacarpophalangeal (MP) joints to be inserted into the lateral side of dorsal digital expansion of the corresponding digit from second to fifth.
  • Nerve supply:
    • 1st and 2nd (Lateral two) are supplied by median nerve.
    • 3rd and 4th (Medial two) are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Actions:
    • Flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and Extension at proximal and distal interphalangeal joints.
    • The lumbricals are tested by asking the subject to flex the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints against resistance.

Key takeaways:


Level: Good to know

Topic: Lumbricals of hand

Reference:

Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume - 1, 4th Edition, Page No - 148, 149

Textbook of anatomy by B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page No - 134, 135

questions.text:
Identify the correct order of below mention Enzymes of Electron Transport Chain starting from NADH

1. ATP Synthase
2. Cytochrome C Oxidoreductase
3. Cytochrome C Oxidase
4. NADH Dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Pathway that an electron takes in the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) starting from NADH, the order of complexes and carriers involved is as follows:

  1. NADH Dehydrogenase (Complex I) - NADH donates electrons to Complex I.
  2. Cytochrome C Oxidoreductase (Complex III) - Electrons are passed from ubiquinone (after Complex I) to Complex III.
  3. Cytochrome C - Electrons are transferred from Complex III to the soluble carrier protein Cytochrome C.
  4. Cytochrome C Oxidase (Complex IV) - Electrons are transferred from Cytochrome C to Complex IV, where they are used to reduce oxygen to water.
  5. ATP Synthase (Complex V) - Protons that were pumped across the membrane during electron transport flow back through ATP Synthase, generating ATP.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, chap 13 page 127

questions.text: What immunological condition predisposes patients to malakoplakia?
questions.solution:
A) HIV infection

  • Can contribute, but not the sole factor.

B) Diabetes mellitus

  • Risk factor, but not primary cause.

C) Immunosuppression

  • Correct: Impaired immune response increases susceptibility.

D) Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Not a direct predisposing factor.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.
  2. Primarily affects immunocompromised patients.
  3. Most commonly associated with E. coli infections.
  4. Characterized by impaired macrophage bactericidal activity.
  5. Can present with various urinary symptoms.
  6. Requires comprehensive diagnostic approach.
  7. Treatment involves antibiotics and addressing underlying immunological issues.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 956.

choices.text: LSIL: abundant cytoplasm, HSIL: scant cytoplasm
LSIL: scant cytoplasm, HSIL: abundant cytoplasm
LSIL: normal cytoplasm, HSIL: abnormal cytoplasm
LSIL: abnormal cytoplasm, HSIL: normal cytoplasm

questions.text: What is the main difference in cytoplasmic features between LSIL and HSIL?
questions.solution:
A) LSIL: abundant cytoplasm, HSIL: scant cytoplasm: This is the correct answer. The main difference in cytoplasmic features between LSIL and HSIL is the amount of cytoplasm, with HSIL showing scant cytoplasm.


B) LSIL: scant cytoplasm, HSIL: abundant cytoplasm: This is incorrect.

C) LSIL: normal cytoplasm, HSIL: abnormal cytoplasm: This is partially correct, but it does not specifically address the difference in cytoplasmic abundance.

D) LSIL: abnormal cytoplasm, HSIL: normal cytoplasm: This is incorrect.

Key Takeaways

he main difference in morphology between low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) and high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) is the amount of cytoplasm in the cells:

  • LSIL: Has abundant cytoplasm, similar to intermediate squamous cells
  • HSIL: Has less or scant cytoplasm, similar to basal and parabasal cells

Other morphological differences between LSIL and HSIL include:

  • Location

LSIL affects the lower part of the cervical lining, while HSIL affects most of it

  • Nuclear abnormalities

LSIL may have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, and high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio

  • LSIL is a diagnostic category for HPV transient infection-related changes, while HSIL is used to categorize precancerous lesions. However, some cases may have equivocal features of both LSIL and HSIL, which are called LSIL-H.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1000.

choices.text: HIV resistance to the current regimen

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a CD4 count of 180 cells/μL and a viral load of 50,000 copies/mL. He has been on antiretroviral therapy (ART) for 2 years. His last CD4 count was 400 cells/μL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his current immunological decline?
questions.solution:
• (A) Poor adherence to antiretroviral therapy: Non-adherence to ART is a common cause of viral rebound and CD4 decline in HIV patients. It leads to inadequate viral suppression and allows for immune system deterioration.
  • (B) HIV resistance to the current regimen: Resistance could be a possibility but usually takes more time to develop and requires specific resistance testing to confirm. It is unlikely without evidence of ongoing viral replication.
  • (C) Acute retroviral syndrome: Typically presents shortly after infection, not after 2 years of treatment. It is characterized by a brief flu-like illness, not the immunological decline observed in this patient.
  • (D) Secondary opportunistic infection: This would not be expected without a significantly lower CD4 count (usually below 200 cells/µL). Opportunistic infections tend to present with lower CD4 counts.

Key Takeaway:

  • Poor adherence to ART is the most common cause of immunological failure in HIV patients on therapy.
  • Key point: Regular monitoring of CD4 count and viral load is essential for managing ART efficacy.

Reference: Ananthanarayan, 9th Edition, Chapter 113

questions.text: Blood spill disinfected by
questions.solution:
Blood spill is common in hospitals and labs.

It can be highly infectious.

Sodium hypochlorite is to be used to clean the spilled blood.

Spray the contaminated surface with a 1-10 solution of sodium hypochlorite and water.

(B)Chlorhexidine is an antiseptic and disinfectant mainly used in mouth or gum diseases.

(A)ethyl alcohol (ethanol) and isopropyl alcohol are the most frequently used. They are used mainly as skin antiseptics at a concentration of 60- 90% in water. They act by denaturing bacterial proteins. They have no action on spores. Proteins slows its action whereas 1 % mineral acid or alkali enhances it. Isopropyl alcohol is preferred as it is a better fat solvent, is more bactericidal and less volatile. It is used for the disinfection of thermometers.

(C) FORMALDEHYDE:

It is a chemical method of sterilization used for

  • OT fumigation
  • formalin (all human specimen stored)
  • Duckering(killing bacillus anthracis spores from animal wool)-process where animal spores treated with formaldehyde

Reference: Apurba sastry 6th edition page no: 20.

questions.text: A 58 year old woman with a long history of depression was brought to the emergency department with vomiting, urinary incontinence, profuse salivation, cold sweat, rapid and irregular pulse, tachypnea and mental confusion. She admitted at tempting suicide by ingesting several tablets found in her husband's drawer. Soon after admission, the woman experienced a tonic-clonic seizure. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's poisoning?
questions.solution:
• The history of the patient, together with her symptoms and signs, is consistent with the diagnosis of nicotine poisoning, likely due to lozenge tablets used by her husband to quit smoking.
  • Nicotine causes a rapid activation of both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, as well as stimulation of different areas of the brain.
  • Signs in this patient due to parasympathetic activation are vomiting, urinary incontinence, and profuse salivation.
  • Signs of sympathetic activation are cold sweat (sweat glands are stimulated and skin vessels const ricted) and rapid and irregular pulse (activation of nicotinic neuronal [Nn] receptors releases epinephrine from adrenal medulla).
  • Central stimulation accounts for the mental confusion and the tonic- clonic seizure.
  • Antidote for Nicotine poisoning: Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium - Nn receptor blockers (ganglionic blockers) are used.

Option A: Clonidine does not cause most of the symptoms exhibited by the patient.

Option B: Scopolamine is used for the prevention of motion sickness. The drug is a muscarinic antagonist; therefore, the symptoms of overdose would be the opposite of those exhibited by the patient.

Option D: Bethanechol is a muscarinic agonist. Symptoms of overdose would be limited to parasympathetic activation.

  • Key takeaway
    • Nicotine causes a rapid activation of both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, as well as stimulation of different areas of the brain.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 133

questions.text: A 50 year old obese man recently diagnosed with vasospastic angina started a treatment with nifedipine. The drug has a volume of distribution (Vd) of about 55 L in a 70-kg person, but in this obese patient, the Vd turned out to be 110 L. The standard loading dose of nifedipine for a patient weighing 70 kg is 30 mg. Which of the following should be the therapeutic loading dose administered to this patient (in mg) in order to achieve the same target concentration?
questions.solution:
• The dose of a drug can be calculated using the equation
    • Loading Dose = (Target plasma concerntration of Drug) * Vd / F
      • *Vd is volume of distribution
      • F = Bioavailability (100% here)
      • The loading dose is equal to the desired drug concentration times the volume of distribution divided by bioavailability.
      • Since the drug is administered intravenously, bioavailability is 100%.

Because the Vd of the obese patient is twice the Vd of a normal-weight person, the dose must be doubled to 60 mg to achieve the same plasma concent ration.

  • Key Takeaway
    • Loading dose: It is mainly used for drugs having long t½ and large volume of distribution. It is given to load (saturate) the tissue stores. So it is mainly dependent on Vd.
      • Loading dose = Vd × Target plasma concentration
      • Loading dose2 = 2× loading dose1 [2×30 =60]

[Good to Know]

[Dosing rate]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 41

questions.text: All of the following are methods to assess contrast sensitivity in a patient, except:
questions.solution:
Contrast Sensitivity Testing

Definition: Contrast sensitivity measures the ability to distinguish subtle changes in contrast and indirectly assesses the "quality" of vision. Unlike visual acuity, which tests sharpness under optimal conditions, contrast sensitivity tests how well a person can perceive objects in low-contrast situations (e.g., night driving or cloudy days).

Methods of Measurement:

  1. Letter Contrast Sensitivity:
    • Tested using charts like Pelli-Robson and Regan charts.
    • Contrast is reduced from 50% to 4%, and the patient is asked to identify the smallest letters possible.
    • The chart is placed 1 meter from the patient.
  2. Sinusoidal Grating Patterns:
    • Bars of varying tilt are presented to the patient, with decreasing contrast.
    • The patient identifies the direction of the tilt.
    • The Cambridge contrast sensitivity gratings use this method, where decreasing contrast is shown until the grating becomes indistinguishable from the background.

Clinical Indications:

  • Contrast sensitivity is especially useful for patients with normal visual acuity but impaired vision in low-contrast conditions (e.g., cataracts, refractive surgery).
  • It is a key test for optic nerve diseases like optic neuritis, multiple sclerosis, papilledema, and possibly glaucoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity also helps in monitoring visual changes over time.

Factors Affecting Contrast Sensitivity:

  • Age: Contrast sensitivity typically declines with age.
  • Refractive errors, glaucoma, diabetes, optic nerve diseases, and lenticular changes (e.g., cataracts) can also impair contrast sensitivity.
  • Even with normal visual acuity, contrast sensitivity may be reduced.

Common Charts for Measurement:

  • Arden Gratings
  • Cambridge Low-Contrast Gratings
  • Pelli-Robson Chart: Uses triplets of low-contrast letters.
  • Visitach Chart
  • Functional Acuity Contrast Test (FACT).

Importance: Contrast sensitivity testing is essential for assessing visual function that cannot be evaluated by traditional visual acuity testing, particularly in conditions where fine detail perception in low-contrast situations is crucial.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, AK Khurana, 6th Edition, page number 17-18, Parson's Diseases of The Eye, 22nd Edition, page number 107

questions.text: Limiting Amino acids in wheat are:
questions.solution:
Deficiency develops due to only consumption of a particular type of food item with limiting amino acids (for e.g. wheat); Thus, two or more food items are eaten together so that their proteins supplement one another; this is known as 'Supplementary Action of Proteins'.

Reference:- Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 11, Page No. 741, 742

choices.text: Bags should have labels for bio-hazard symbol and cytotoxic hazard symbol
Labels should be washable and prominently visible
Triple layered bags should be used for collection of waste from COVID-19 Isolation wards
All of the following are correct

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about the bags used for biomedical waste management?
questions.solution:
• The biomedical waste should be segregated into containers/bags at the point of generation of the waste.
  • The bags should have the label for bio-hazards symbol and cytotoxic hazard symbol which should be prominently visible and non-washable.
  • For COVID-19, foot operated lids in colour coded bins must be introduced to avoid contact. General solid waste should not be contaminated by patients secretions and body fluids. Wet and dry solid waste bags must be tied securely.
  • As precaution, double layered bags (using 2 bags) should be used for collection of waste from COVID-19 isolation wards so as to ensure adequate strength and no leaks. It should be labelled as COVID-19 Waste.
  • All the waste handlers must follow the preventive measures like hand washing, using gloves, and mask, and other personal protective equipment.

Reference: - Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no. 920.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to toxic multinodular goiter

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, fatigue, and palpitations. On examination, her thyroid is diffusely enlarged, and she has a fine tremor in her hands. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is undetectable, and free thyroxine (T4) is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Graves' disease is the most likely diagnosis, as it presents with hyperthyroidism, diffuse thyroid enlargement, and elevated free T4 with suppressed TSH.
  • Option B: Toxic multinodular goiter typically presents with variable thyroid function tests and multiple palpable thyroid nodules, which are not described here.
  • Option C: Thyroid carcinoma would present with a hard, non-tender thyroid nodule and typically no hyperthyroidism.
  • Option D: Subclinical hyperthyroidism typically has normal symptoms and mildly suppressed TSH.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Graves' disease presents with diffuse thyroid enlargement, hyperthyroidism, and elevated T4 with suppressed TSH.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with back pain and elevated alkaline phosphatase. X-rays show vertebral fractures, bone sclerosis, and thickened cortical bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Osteoporosis leads to fragility fractures, but it does not cause bone sclerosis or thickened cortical bone seen in this patient.

OPTION B - Paget's disease of bone causes bone remodeling with bone sclerosis, fractures, and thickened cortical bone. It can present with bone pain and elevated alkaline phosphatase.

OPTION C - Multiple myeloma typically presents with punched-out lesions on X-ray and elevated serum calcium and protein levels, not sclerosis.

OPTION D - Metastatic bone disease usually causes lytic lesions and bone destruction, not sclerosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Paget's disease of bone is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling leading to enlarged, brittle bones.
  2. Bone pain, fractures, and elevated alkaline phosphatase are common findings.

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 312 PAGE 3210

choices.text: Immediate incision and drainage of the abscess under local anesthesia
Refer to a breast surgeon for evaluation of breast cancer

questions.text:
A 32-year-old breastfeeding woman presents with a painful, swollen, erythematous mass in her right breast, associated with fever and fatigue. The mass is firm and tender on examination, with no fluctuation. She also has tender axillary lymph nodes. She has no history of trauma or surgery, but this is her first episode of such symptoms.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Acute mastitis can occur in lactating as well as non-lactating women, with the former being more common.

The incidence of acute mastitis in lactating mothers ranges from 3% to 20%, with Staphylococcus aureus being the most common cause. Abscess formation typically occurs at two key stages:

  1. First month postpartum due to inexperience or improper breastfeeding.
  2. During weaning caused by engorgement and nipple trauma from the baby's teeth.

If left untreated, acute mastitis in breastfeeding women often progresses from generalized cellulitis to abscess formation. Cellulitis initially presents with erythema, pain, and swelling. If not addressed, it can progress to an abscess, which is typically fluctuant. However, in the case of a deep-seated abscess, fluctuation may be absent. Associated symptoms include fever, malaise, difficulty feeding, and tender axillary lymph nodes.

Ultrasonography is essential for diagnosis, revealing increased echogenicity (cellulitis) and a hypoechoic collection (pus) with floating debris, indicating liquefaction necrosis.

In such cases, the most appropriate management step is ultrasound-guided drainage to accurately drain the abscess, especially in deep-seated abscesses where fluctuation may not be palpable.

Option A: A breast support garment, cold compression on the breast (Not warm), and analgesia aid in symptomatic relief. During the cellulitic stage, the patient should be treated with anti-staphylococcal antibiotics such as cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, or erythromycin. Breastfeeding should be actively continued from both breasts with frequent emptying of the affected breast.

Option B: Contrary to the practice of incision and drainage, ultrasound-guided drainage in a breast abscess gives an excellent cosmetic result, does not hamper breastfeeding, and can be done as a day-care procedure with a high success rate.

Option C: This option is correct. In abscesses >3 cm in diameter or those containing more than 30 mL of pus (assessed on ultrasonography), a vacuum suction catheter is inserted under ultrasound guidance to drain the pus

Option D: Most of the cases of breast cancer are painless. Hence this option is not correct. Key Takeaway Point:

Treatment requires antibiotics and frequent emptying of the breast. True abscesses require drainage. Initial attempts at drainage should include needle aspiration; surgical incision and drainage should be reserved for abscesses that do not resolve after aspiration and treatment with antibiotics. In such cases, abscesses are generally multiloculated.

Ultrasound evaluation can assist in characterizing a breast abscess and help to guide needle aspiration.

Antibiotics should be continued for 14 days.

References:

  1. Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 927
  2. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Ed - Page 826

choices.text: All of the above are causes

questions.text: Which of the following are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma ?
questions.solution:
The major risk factor in Western practice is PSC. It is estimated that a longstanding history of PSC increases the risk of developing biliary tract cancer 20-fold compared with the normal population; those with concomitant IBD are at significantly higher risk.

Option B:(Sabiston) Historically, the most common risk factors for the development of cholangiocarcinoma (all types) were primary sclerosing cholangitis, choledochal cyst disease, hepatolithiasis, and RPC. Recent epidemiologic evidence has now linked IHC to HBV infection, HCV infection, cirrhosis, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, and diabetes.

Option C :

Congenital cystic disease, hepatolithiasis, oriental cholangiohepatitis, hepatitis C virus infection, and infestation with liver flukes have also been associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

Reason: While the pathophysiology is unclear, it is thought that these parasites cause chronic inflammation that leads to DNA mutations through the production of carcinogens and free radicals; the latter can stimulate cellular proliferation in the intrahepatic bile ducts and ultimately lead to invasive cancer

All of the above are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma ( Based on Sabiston and Schwartz's textbook of surgery).

Schwartz: Most cases of extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma develop de novo with no identifiable risk factors.

However, there is an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts, ulcerative colitis, hepatolithiasis, biliary-enteric anastomoses, hepatitis B and C, cirrhosis, biliary tract infections with Clonorchis (liver flukes), and chronic typhoid carriers. Exposure to dietary nitrosamines, Thorotrast, or dioxin also puts patients at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma.

Key Takeaway Points:


  • Cholangiocarcinoma appears to occur at an earlier age in patients with PSC (30-50 years of age) than in the general population.
  • In addition, the disease is usually multifocal and detected at an advanced stage, resulting in a poor prognosis compared with the general population.

References:

  1. Sabiston textbook of Surgery 21st Ed - Page 1471
  2. Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 1256
  3. Schwartz textbook of Surgery 11th Ed - Page 1423

questions.text: The HabrGama protocol is followed in which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Approximately 20% of rectal cancers treated by neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy show a complete clinical response with no evidence of residual cancer on clinical examination, biopsy, or radiological imaging.

There is an increasing trend for such patients to be offered the option of 'watch and wait' (HabrGama) in the hope that they may have been cured of the disease and spared the morbidity of resectional surgery. Some 30% of cases will recur on a 'watch and wait' policy, but surgical resection can salvage most.

Key Take Away Point:

HabrGama protocol is followed in rectal cancers.

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 1409

choices.text: The Half-life of circulating PTH is 3-5mins
The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection
A drop in PTH levels to half the maximum of preoperative levels at 10 mins is predictive of multi-gland disease
Intra operative PTH guides the surgeon about when to stop the parathyroid exploration

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the "Miami criteria"
questions.solution:
Concept: Intraoperative PTH measurements may guide the need to convert from a focused to a cervical exploration.

Option C: A drop in the plasma PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease. Therefore, a significant drop should be detected in the plasma PTH following the resection of a single adenoma. If no such drop is detected, then multi-gland disease may be suspected, and conversion to a bilateral neck exploration should be considered.

Other options:

Option A: The basic concept is that the half-life of circulating PTH is 3-5 minutes

Option B: The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection.

Option D: IOPTH monitoring is a commonly used adjunct, which guides the surgeon on when to stop the parathyroid exploration. It helps confirm that there is no residual hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

The Miami criteria is a protocol used to determine if a parathyroid tumor has been successfully removed. It's based on a 50% decrease in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels within 10 minutes after surgery.

How does the Miami criteria work?

A blood sample is taken before the incision

Another blood sample is taken 10 minutes after the tumor is removed

The PTH level in the second sample is compared to the first

If the PTH level has decreased by more than 50%, the surgery is considered successful

Key Takeaway Point:

Pitfall: Routine use is controversial due to high false-positive and false-negative rates.

Reference:

  1. Bailey and Love 28th - Page 880
  2. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Ed - Page 932

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT included in the calculation of the Thoracoscore, a scoring system used to predict mortality following thoracic surgery?
questions.solution:
The Thoracic Surgery Scoring System (Thoracoscore) is the most widely used model to assess the risk of operative mortality in thoracic patients. Risk is calculated based on nine variables: Age, Sex, American Society of Anaesthesiologist's score, Performance status, Dyspnoea score, Priority of surgery, Extent of surgery, Malignant diagnosis and Composite comorbidity score.

It is currently the most robust model available to estimate the risk of death when considering patients for thoracic surgery.

Key Takeaway Point:


Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 975

questions.text: In an eFAST examination, which of the following ultrasound probe configurations is most appropriate for balancing penetration depth and image resolution to assess both thoracic and abdominal trauma effectively?
questions.solution:
Medical ultrasound uses frequencies in the range of 3-20 MHz. The higher the frequency of the ultrasound wave, the greater the resolution of the image, but the less depth of view from the skin. Consequently, abdominal imaging uses transducers with a frequency of 3-7 MHz, while higher frequency transducers are used for superficial structures, such as musculoskeletal and breast ultrasound.

"Curvilinear probe" is used for focused assessment of sonolography of trauma [FAST]

Key Take Away Point:


Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 120

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leads to Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, particularly in chronic alcohol users.

OPTION B - Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neuropathy, but it does not cause this triad of symptoms.

OPTION C - Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, not Wernicke's encephalopathy.

OPTION D - Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia and rickets, not neurological symptoms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Wernicke's encephalopathy requires prompt treatment with parenteral thiamine to prevent progression to Korsakoff syndrome.
  2. Chronic alcohol use impairs thiamine absorption and storage.

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 333 PAGE 2526

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic clinical feature of congestive heart failure (CHF)?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Chest pain is not a cardinal symptom of CHF but can occur in cases of acute coronary syndrome.
  • Option B: Dyspnea (difficulty breathing) and fatigue are the hallmark symptoms of CHF due to decreased cardiac output and pulmonary congestion.
  • Option C: While an increased heart rate may be present as a compensatory mechanism, it is not considered a characteristic clinical feature of CHF.
  • Option D: Palpitations can occur due to arrhythmias but are not a defining feature of CHF.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The common symptoms of CHF include dyspnea, fatigue, and fluid retention, resulting from the heart's inability to pump blood effectively.

REFERENCE: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 257, page 1930

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with episodic headache, sweating, and palpitations. Which test is most specific for diagnosing pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Serum cortisol levels are not relevant in diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

OPTION B - Urinary free catecholamines are sensitive but less specific compared to plasma metanephrines.

OPTION C - Hypokalemia is associated with primary hyperaldosteronism, not pheochromocytoma.

OPTION D - Plasma metanephrines are the most specific and sensitive diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pheochromocytoma diagnosis relies on biochemical testing, with plasma metanephrines being the gold standard.

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 387 PAGE 2977

questions.text: The "big four" NCDs (cardiovascular diseases, cancers, chronic respiratory diseases, and diabetes) account for what percentage of premature NCD deaths?
questions.solution:
Key facts

  • Noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) kill 41 million people each year, equivalent to 74% of all deaths globally.
  • Each year, 17 million people die from a NCD before age 70; 86% of these premature deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries.
  • Of all NCD deaths, 77% are in low- and middle-income countries.
  • Cardiovascular diseases account for most NCD deaths, or 17.9 million people annually, followed by cancers (9.3 million), chronic respiratory diseases (4.1 million), and diabetes (2.0 million including kidney disease deaths caused by diabetes).
  • These four groups of diseases account for over 80% of all premature NCD deaths.
  • Tobacco use, physical inactivity, the harmful use of alcohol, unhealthy diets and air pollution all increase the risk of dying from an NCD.
  • Detection, screening and treatment of NCDs, as well as palliative care, are key components of the response to NCDs.

Reference: World Health Organization: WHO. Noncommunicable diseases [Internet]. 2023. Available from: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/noncommunicable-diseases

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painful, red eye, blurred vision, and a history of contact lens use. On examination, there is a central corneal ulcer with a yellow-white infiltrate and hypopyon. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Bacterial Corneal Ulcers

Causative Organisms:

  • Bacterial corneal ulcers are often caused by pyogenic bacteria such as Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus aureus, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Escherichia coli, and others.
  • gonorrhoeae and Corynebacterium diphtheriae are the only bacteria that can invade intact corneal epithelium. Other bacteria like pneumococci cause ulceration after epithelium damage.

Mode and Source of Infection:

  • Organisms typically enter through breaks in the corneal epithelium due to trauma, reduced resistance, or preexisting conditions (e.g., dry eyes, contact lenses, entropion).
  • Specific risk factors include trauma, steroid use, dry eyes, neurotrophic keratitis, and poor hygiene.

Pathology:

  • Corneal ulcer presents as a breach in the epithelium with necrosis of corneal layers.
  • The ulcer has a saucer shape with swelling around the edges, often surrounded by a grey zone of leucocyte infiltration.
  • Bacterial toxins irritate the iris and ciliary body, leading to keratouveitis and hypopyon.
  • Vascularization and immune response help control infection, leading to healing and potential scar formation.

Healing and Scarring:

  • As the ulcer heals, the necrotic material sheds, and the corneal tissue regenerates.
  • Fibrous tissue replaces the damaged corneal layers, leading to a scar. The scar may be opaque, especially if Bowman's membrane is destroyed.
  • Vascularization aids in healing, and scars can become more transparent over time.
  • In severe cases, corneal facets may remain, which can affect vision.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of The Eye, 22nd Edition, page number 199-205

questions.text: All of the following organisms cause infectious hypopyon though intact cornea, except:
questions.solution:
Etiology

There are two main factors in the production of purulent corneal ulcer:

  • Damage to corneal epithelium; and
  • Infection of the eroded area.

However, following three pathogens can invade the intact corneal epithelium and produce ulceration: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Neisseria meningitidis.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, AK Khurana, 6th Edition, page number 99

questions.text: Which of the following is a key laboratory test for diagnosing poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Incorrect. The VDRL test is used for diagnosing syphilis, not poliomyelitis.
  • Option B: Correct. The gold standard for diagnosing poliomyelitis is the isolation of the virus from throat swabs, rectal swabs, or stool samples. It helps confirm active infection.
  • Option C: Incorrect. PCR testing for Treponema pallidum DNA is used for diagnosing syphilis, not poliomyelitis.
  • Option D: Incorrect. While CSF analysis can be helpful in diagnosing meningitis or other CNS infections, it is not specific for poliomyelitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • The primary method for diagnosing poliomyelitis is virus isolation from throat or stool samples.
  • PCR and antigen detection techniques are used to identify and serotype the poliovirus.
  • Reference:

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed, Chapter 73, Pg 713.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary vector for Babesia microti?
questions.solution:
Babesia microti, the most common cause of human babesiosis in the United States, is primarily transmitted by the Ixodes scapularis tick, also known as the black-legged or deer tick.

  1. Overview:
    • Cause: Protozoan parasites of the genus Babesia.
    • Transmission: Primarily through the bite of infected Ixodes scapularis ticks (black-legged or deer ticks).
  2. Symptoms:
    • Common: Fever, chills, sweating, headache, muscle pain, and fatigue.
    • Severe: High fever, hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and organ dysfunction.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Microscopy: Blood smears show intra-erythrocytic Babesia
    • PCR Testing: Detects Babesia DNA in the blood.
    • Serology: Detects antibodies against Babesia.
  4. Treatment:
    • Uncomplicated Cases: Atovaquone + Azithromycin for 7-10 days.
    • Severe Cases: Clindamycin + Quinine.
    • Pregnant Women: Clindamycin + Quinine is preferred.
  5. Prevention:
    • Avoid Tick Bites: Use repellents, wear protective clothing, and perform tick checks.
    • Tick Removal: Remove ticks promptly with fine-tipped tweezers and clean the bite area.
  6. Geographic Distribution:
    • Common in: Northeastern and north-central United States.

Reference: CDC Bebesiosis

questions.text: A 53 year old man continued to have a low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol level of 270 mg/dL after a 6-month trial of diet therapy. His triglyceride levels were in the normal range. The patient had been suffering from type II diabetes mellitus for 2 years and peptic ulcer for 4 months. Current therapy included glyburide and metformin for diabetes and omeprazole for peptic ulcer. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to treat this patient's hyperlipidemia?
questions.solution:
• Currently, statins represent the most effective and best tolerated agents for treating dyslipidemia.
  • They are effective in all types of dyslipidemia, and when given as a single agent, they may decrease low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol up to 55% and total cholesterol up to 35%.
  • Therefore, they are the drugs of choice for treatment of elevated LDL cholesterol. Higher doses can also reduce triglyceride levels up to 35%.

Statins

  • HMG CoA reductase catalyses the rate limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis (conversion of HMG CoA to mevalonate).
  • Statins act by inhibiting this enzyme competitively and result in decreased cholesterol synthesis in the liver.
  • As liver requires cholesterol for synthesis of bile acids and steroid hormones, it responds by increasing the uptake of LDL from the plasma.
  • This is done by increasing LDL receptors on its surface. Statins are most powerful LDL lowering agents.
  • These drugs also lower TG, IDL and VLDL and increases HDL slightly.

Option A: Niacin should be avoided because of diabetes and peptic ulcer.

Option B: Cholestyramine is relatively contraindicated because it could impair the absorption of the other currently used drugs.

Option D: Fibrates such as gem brozil are the drugs of choice for treating type III hyperlipidemia (familial dysbetalipoproteinemia), as well as high triglyceride levels. They do not signicantly decrease LDL.

Key takeaway:

  • Statins represent the most effective and best tolerated agents for treating dyslipidemia. They are effective in all types of dyslipidemia, and when given as a single agent, they may decrease low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol up to 55% and total cholesterol up to 35%.

[Good to Know]

[Lovastatin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 684

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient presents with fever, headache, and confusion. Lumbar puncture is performed and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals the following:
CSF pressure: 200 mm of water
Total leukocyte count: 8,000/mm3
Predominant cell type: Neutrophils
Glucose: 25 mg/dL
Total proteins: 300 mg/dL

Based on the CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Pyogenic meningitis: The CSF pressure is elevated (>180 mm of water), the total leukocyte count is very high (8,000/mm3), predominantly neutrophils, with low glucose (<40 mg/dL) and elevated proteins (>250 mg/dL), which are hallmark features of pyogenic meningitis.
  • B) Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis typically shows moderately elevated CSF proteins (100-500 mg/dL), lymphocytes as the predominant cell type, and a slightly decreased glucose (20-40 mg/dL), not the markedly elevated neutrophils and low glucose seen here.
  • C) Viral meningitis: In viral meningitis, CSF typically shows lymphocytes as the predominant cell type, a moderate rise in total leukocyte count (25-500/mm3), and a normal glucose level, which does not match the CSF findings in this case.
  • D) Fungal meningitis: Fungal meningitis often presents with a predominance of lymphocytes and normal/slightly elevated proteins (20-80 mg/dL), along with a normal glucose level, making it inconsistent with the features presented in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pyogenic meningitis typically shows a high CSF pressure, a neutrophilic predominance, low glucose levels, and markedly elevated proteins.
  • Tuberculous and viral meningitis generally present with lymphocytic predominance and milder changes in CSF glucose and protein levels.

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed, Chapter 71, Pg 693.

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic patient presented with right sided severe ear ache, rapidly progressing infection in the external auditory canal with involvement of bone and presence of granulation tissue. What will be the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa, also known as necrotizing otitis externa or malignant external otitis (MEO), is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.

The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in elderly patients with diabetes. The infection begins as an external otitis that progresses into an osteomyelitis of the temporal bone. Spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini and the osseocartilaginous junction.

The pain is out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Marked tenderness is present in the soft tissue between the mandibular ramus and mastoid tip.

Granulation tissue is present at the floor of the osseocartilaginous junction. This finding is virtually pathognomonic of malignant external otitis (MEO). Otoscopic examination may also reveal exposed bone.

Treatment includes meticulous glucose control, aural toilet, systemic and ototopic antimicrobial therapy. Fluoroquinolones that attain high soft tissue and bone levels with oral doses were then developed. Subsequently, several authors have demonstrated the efficacy of oral ciprofloxacin monotherapy.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 62.

questions.text: Which technology is used in 99 DOTS to ensure medication adherence in TB patients?
questions.solution:
• 99 DOTS: it is low-cost strategy for monitoring and improving medication adherence. Under this patient send a free call each time they take their medication, so that providers can monitor adherence calls. Patient's medication is packaged in custom secondary envelops with add dosage instruction, and a series of hidden numbers behind the pills. Each time a patient takes a dose of medication, a hidden number is revealed which is unpredictable to the patient. The revealed number completes a phone number, where the first part of the number is printed on the front side of the envelope. The patient then makes a free call to the completed phone number.
  • Nikshay: TB surveillance using care based, web-based IT system. The software was launched in May 2012 and has following functional components: master management, user details, TB patient registration and details of diagnosis, DOTS provider, HIV status, follow up, contact tracing, outcomes etc, details of solid and liquid culture and DST, LPA, CBNAAT details, DR-TB patient registration with details, referral and transfer of patients, private health facility registration and TB notification, mobile application for TB notification, SMS alerts to patients on registration, SMS alerts to programme officers, automated periodic reports.
  • Nikshay poshan Abhiyan: it is a government scheme in India that was announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in April of 2018 with the aim of helping tuberculosis patient. The scheme is working towards betterment of patients with tuberculosis (TB) by providing them with 500 rupees per month to buy food. If the patient is tribal with drug resistant tuberculosis government provide 750 rupees per month.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 7, Page No. 488

questions.text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of classic heatstroke (CHS) compared to exertional heatstroke (EHS)?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Profuse diaphoresis is characteristic of EHS, not CHS

OPTION B - CHS is associated with hypernatremia secondary to dehydration, a feature resulting from limited access to fluids and a sedentary state.

OPTION C - Rhabdomyolysis is common in EHS due to intense muscular exertion.

OPTION D - Hyponatremia and hypoglycemia are more typical in EHS.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Differences between classic and exertional heat stroke.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, chapter 465, page 3637

MEN 1 is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder. It was originally called Wermer's syndrome. It presents as PHPT, Pancreatic islet cell tumors, and Pituitary tumors. MEN 1 is also associated with meningiomas and facial angiofibroma.

questions.text: According to Spaulding's classification of medical devices, which of the following is the correct method of decontamination for critical devices (high risk) that enter a normally sterile site?
questions.solution:
• A) Sterilization: This is the correct answer. Critical devices are items that enter a normally sterile site (e.g., surgical instruments, implants, syringes), and they require sterilization to ensure complete elimination of all microbial life.
  • B) High-level disinfection (HLD): This method is used for semi-critical devices (e.g., respiratory equipment, flexible endoscopes) that come into contact with mucous membranes or body fluids, not for critical devices.
  • C) Low-level disinfection (LLD): This method is used for non-critical devices (e.g., blood pressure cuffs, stethoscopes), which only contact intact skin, not for critical devices.
  • D) Intermediate-level disinfection (ILD): This method is used for semi-critical devices, but not for critical devices. It is used for items that contact mucous membranes or body fluids.

Key Takeaways:

  • Critical devices require sterilization because they enter sterile sites and must be free of all microorganisms.
  • Devices classified as semi-critical or non-critical are cleaned using varying levels of disinfection based on their contact with body tissues.
  • Spaulding's classification helps determine the appropriate decontamination method based on the risk level associated with medical devices.

questions.text: The glomerulus is a critical component of the renal corpuscle, responsible for filtering waste and excess fluids from the blood. Which of the following structures is NOT a component of the glomerulus?
questions.solution:
1. Capillary endothelial cells: Capillary endothelial cells line the glomerular capillaries and play a crucial role in the filtration process.
  2. Podocytes: Podocytes are specialized epithelial cells that wrap around the glomerular capillaries, forming foot processes that help filter waste and excess fluids.
  3. Mesangial cells: Mesangial cells are specialized cells that provide structural support to the glomerulus and help regulate blood flow.
  4. Collecting duct cells: Collecting duct cells are part of the renal collecting duct system and are not a component of the glomerulus.

Key Takeaways:

  1. The glomerulus is a critical component of the renal corpuscle: The glomerulus is responsible for filtering waste and excess fluids from the blood.
  2. The glomerulus is composed of capillary endothelial cells, podocytes, and mesangial cells: These cells work together to filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

Reference: Robbins and cotran, 10th edition, page no. 898.

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include:

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

  • Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters and local lymph node enlargements.
  • Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.
  • Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 35th edition, Page no. 425-428

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back, along with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. On examination, the patient is hypertensive, and a new diastolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border. A chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Myocardial infarction typically presents with chest pain, but not with radiating pain to the back and a widened mediastinum.
  • Option B: The most likely diagnosis is aortic dissection, which presents with severe chest pain, hypertensive crisis, and a widened mediastinum on X-ray. The new diastolic murmur suggests aortic valve insufficiency secondary to dissection.
  • Option C: Acute pericarditis presents with pleuritic chest pain and a pericardial friction rub, not a widened mediastinum.
  • Option D: Pulmonary embolism can cause chest pain and shortness of breath but does not cause a widened mediastinum or a diastolic murmur.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Aortic dissection presents with acute severe chest pain, hypertensive crisis, and a widened mediastinum.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 280, page 2103

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, and a persistent dry cough for the last two weeks. His past medical history includes smoking and recent exposure to a coworker with similar symptoms. Chest X-ray shows a consolidation in the right lower lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Community-acquired pneumonia is the most likely diagnosis given the fever, cough, and consolidation on chest X-ray, particularly in a smoker with exposure to a colleague with similar symptoms.
  • Option B: Tuberculosis typically presents with a chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, not a sudden onset like this.
  • Option C: Lung cancer generally does not present with fever and consolidation on X-ray.
  • Option D: Sarcoidosis can cause lung involvement, but it would not present with a localized consolidation on chest X-ray.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Community-acquired pneumonia presents with fever, cough, and consolidation on chest X-ray, especially in smokers.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 126, page 1011

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was admit ted to the emergency department with the chief complaint of an excruciating pain in his left ankle. The pain had started the previous night and increased over several hours. The patient reported that he sprained his ankle 1 week ago. On physical examination, the ankle appeared warm and tender and the entire area was red and swollen. A synovial fluid analysis showed crystals engulfed by phagocytes. A diagnosis was made and a pharmacotherapy was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to treat the patient's pain?
questions.solution:
• The patient's signs and symptoms suggest that he is sufferring from an acute gout attack.
  • Although the metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most common joint affected by gout attack, other joints can be involved.
  • The gout attack can be precipitated by over indulgence in purine-rich foods, alcohol, infect ion, or minor trauma, as in this case.
  • Systemic treatment of acute gout at tacks includes oral nonsteroidal

Anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or colchicine.

  • NSAIDs such as indomethacin are often preferred because of the frequent and sometimes serious adverse effects of colchicine.
  • Glucocorticoids administered intraarticularly after joint aspiration can be an effective and safe treatment for a gout attack.

Indomethacin

  • This indole acetic acid derivative is a potent anti-inflammatory drug with prompt antipyretic action.
  • Indomethacin relieves only inflammatory or tissue injury related pain.
  • It is a highly potent inhibitor of PG synthesis and suppresses neutrophil motility. In toxic doses it uncouples oxidative phosphorylation (like aspirin).

Uses of Indomethacin:

  • Because of prominent adverse effects, indomethacin is used as a reserve drug in conditions requiring potent anti-inflammatory action like
    • Ankylosing spondylitis,
    • Acute exacerbations of destructive arthropathies,
    • Psoriatic arthritis
    • Acute gout or rheumatoid arthritis that are not responding to better tolerated NSAIDs.
  • Malignancy associated fever refractory to other antipyretics may respond to indomethacin.
  • It has been the most common drug used for medical closure of patent ductus arteriosus: three 12 hourly i.v. injections of 0.1-0.2 mg/kg achieve closure in majority of cases.
  • Bartter's syndrome responds dramatically, as it does to other PG synthesis inhibitors.

Option A: Codeine is a weak opioid analgesic devoid of antiinflammatory properties and is of no value in gout attack.

Option C: Methotrexate and etanercept are effective in rheumatoid arthritis but are of no value in gouty arthritis.

Option D: NSAIDs other than indomethacin have been proved effective in the treatment of acute gouty arthritis. When given in small doses, aspirin can inhibit the excretion of uric acid by the kidney, so it should not be used for analgesia in patients with gout.

Key takeaway

  • Indomethacin relieves only inflammatory or tissue injury related pain.
  • It is a highly potent inhibitor of PG synthesis and suppresses neutrophil motility. In toxic doses it uncouples oxidative phosphorylation (like aspirin).

[Must Know]

[Indomethacin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 219

questions.text: A 25-year-old medical student with no history of exposure to hepatitis B has recently been vaccinated for the virus. Which of the following choices represent his status?

OPTION A - Represents a person with past infection (anti-HBc positive) who now has immunity (anti-HBs positive).

OPTION B - In patients who develop immunity due to HBV vaccination, all markers are negative except for hepatitis B surface antibody.

OPTION C - is a person who has active infection.

OPTION D - is a person who has never been exposed to hepatitis B but can be susceptible to the virus.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: HBsAg is a marker infection, HBeAg is a marker of high infectivity and antiHBs reflects vaccination or remote past infection.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, chapter339, table5

questions.text: A 34-year old male, farmer by profession, came to the casualty with history of redness, pain and discharge in left eye since 1 week. He had history of trauma to the left eye with thorn 10days back. On examination, the visual acuity in left eye was 6/60 with circumcorneal congestion. There was presence of whitish lesion on cornea which was fluorescein stain positive. Which of the following statement is FALSE about the given condition.
questions.solution:
Fungal Corneal Infections (Mycotic Keratitis)

Overview:

  • Prevalence: Common in tropical regions, rural areas, and immunocompromised individuals.
  • Causative Agents: Typically caused by Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans.
  • Mode of Infection: Often follows trauma with vegetable matter (e.g., thorn or stick).

Symptoms:

  • Milder symptoms compared to bacterial ulcers despite pronounced clinical signs.

Signs:

  • Slough: Dry, feathery borders, surrounded by a yellow demarcation line.
  • Hypopyon: Thick, immobile, due to fungal invasion into the anterior chamber.
  • Immune Ring: Visible due to immune complex deposition.
  • Satellite Lesions: Often present.
  • Congestion: Marked ciliary and conjunctival congestion with less pain and photophobia.

Complications:

  1. Keratectasia (Ectatic Cicatrix):
  2. Keratocele (Descemetocele):
  3. Perforation:
  4. Secondary Glaucoma:
  5. Anterior Staphyloma:
  6. Anterior Capsular Cataract:
  7. Corneal Fistula:
  8. Lens and Vitreous Expulsion:
  9. Haemorrhage:
  10. Infections:

Reference: Parson's Diseases of The Eye, 22nd Edition, page number 201-203.

choices.text: Initiate antisecretory therapy and broad-spectrum antibiotics; proceed to surgery if no improvement is seen in 6 hours

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of arthritis treated with NSAIDs presents with acute abdominal pain and pneumoperitoneum. His symptoms began 6 hours ago. After receiving 1 liter of normal saline, his vital signs have stabilized. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment for perforated duodenal ulcers is prompt surgery after resuscitation. Nonoperative management is only appropriate for select cases, such as old, contained perforations or terminally ill patients unable to tolerate surgery.

Option A:

The diagnosis of perforation is often clinical and confirmed radiographically (pneumoperitoneum). However, when clinical suspicion is high and radiographic findings support it, immediate surgery is preferred over further diagnostic imaging.

Option B:

The management of perforated ulcers focuses on resuscitation and surgical repair, not endoscopy, which may be performed later in stable patients to assess ulcer healing or H. pylori status.

Option C:

While antisecretory therapy and antibiotics are critical components of postoperative care and H. pylori eradication, they do not replace the need for immediate surgical repair in acute perforations.

Key Takeaway Point:

  • Patients who have had one perforation may have another.
  • Therefore, they should be managed aggressively to ensure this does not happen.
  • Lifelong treatment with PPIs is a reasonable option, especially for those who have to continue with NSAID treatment.

Reference: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed, Page 1165

questions.text: Unilateral purulent nasal discharge in a 4 year old baby is commonly due to?
questions.solution:
Nasal foreign bodies (NFB) are commonly seen in the emergency department mostly in the pediatric population, however, they might be seen in adults with psychiatric illness or developmental disabilities.

NFBs are usually benign and do not require urgent intervention, however, some objects can cause severe damage and need to be removed urgently, these include things like batteries and magnets. The nasal foreign body may be obvious or may require a high index of suspicion as they may present acutely but can be missed and remain for weeks, months, or even years after insertion.

Basically, foreign bodies are classified as animate and inanimate or organic and inorganic. In general, the organic foreign bodies tend to be more irritating to the nasal mucosa and tend to cause symptoms much earlier.

Patients usually present with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge that is usually unilateral. NFBs are usually painless, however, some children present with headaches on the same side of the foreign body. Moreover, bloody stained discharge or even epistasis might be witnessed in these cases.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 192.

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Saturnine gout refers to gout-like symptoms caused by chronic lead poisoning.
  • Lead exposure can interfere with the kidney's ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood).
  • This can result in the deposition of urate crystals in the joints, causing gout-like symptoms.
  • This condition was historically seen in people exposed to lead, such as those who drank wine sweetened with lead or worked in industries with high lead exposure.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Cadmium poisoning: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, but it is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.
  • Option C - Beryllium poisoning: Beryllium poisoning is associated with lung disease (berylliosis) and is not directly linked to Saturnine gout.
  • Option D - Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning primarily affects the nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as tremors, cognitive impairments, and sensory disturbances. It is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Lead exposure can interfere with the kidney's ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 546

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and immediate surgical debridement

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with severe perineal pain, swelling, and crepitus. His skin shows necrosis, and he has leukocytosis and elevated lactate. What is the most critical next step in management?
questions.solution:
Fournier Gangrene is a frequently tested topic in Neet PG/Fmge.

Option D: It is a fulminant form of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal, genital, or perianal regions, commonly affecting elderly men, but can also occur in women and children.

Who is at risk? FG has been associated with diabetes, chronic alcohol abuse, and immuno suppression, although it can occur in healthy patients without significant comorbidities

Causative organism? FG is typically associated with a mixed flora, both aerobic and anaerobic. Cultures from the wounds commonly show Klebsiella, streptococci, staphylococci, clostridia, Bacteroides, and corynebacteria.

Signs and symptoms: The local signs and symptoms may include intense pain and swelling. Crepitus of the inflamed tissues is a common feature because of the presence of gas-forming organisms. As the subcutaneous inflammation worsens, necrotic patches appear over the overlying skin and progress to more extensive necrosis.

Fate of the infection: FG is a surgical emergency: it is usually rapidly progressive and quickly leads to sepsis, potentially with multiple organ failure and even death. Regardless of the cause of FG, the testes are usually spared as the blood supply originates intraabdominal.

Treatment: Treatment of FG requires an aggressive multimodal approach, including hemodynamic stabilization and broad-spectrum antibiotics; however, early aggressive surgical debridement should be commenced without delay. It must be emphasized that early surgical debridement is the cornerstone of treatment and if delayed, may have a negative impact on prognosis.

Option A: Though insulin dosage and infusions may be required, it's not the most critical step in the management of this patient, since it is a surgical emergency.

Option B: Imaging is often not necessary in the case of a septic patient, as the delay in treatment may lead to mortality.

Option C: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is a newer modality involved in the treatment of Necrotising fascitis, but source control in the form of surgical debridement has to be done prior to it.

Key take away Point:

Reference: Sabiston textbook of Surgery, 21st Ed, Page 1417; Bailey and Love, 28th Ed, Page 1573

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a left pulmonary contusion, open comminuted left femur fracture, and mild head injury (GCS 12) develops confusion, hypoxemia (88% saturation), and a petechial rash on his chest and axillae 40 hours after a motorcycle crash. He was in skeletal traction, on antibiotics, and supplemental oxygen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: This is the most likely diagnosis. The patient has risk factors (a long bone fracture and trauma) and presents with classic signs of FES: confusion, hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 88%), and a petechial rash. Symptoms typically develop within 24-72 hours after the injury, which aligns with the timeline in this case.

Option A: ADR can present with confusion and rashes, but is mostly provoked by infusion of certain drugs or fluids. The question does not have such data.

Option C: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia could lead to petechiae due to low platelet counts. However, it usually presents with more generalized thrombocytopenic symptoms, such as easy bruising or significant bleeding. It would not explain the symptoms of hypoxemia, confusion, or timing as effectively as FES.

Option D: Though a drop in GCS signifies traumatic brain injury. The hypoxemia and rashes are not explained. Hence this option is wrong

Key Take Away Point:

  • Fat emboli syndrome (FES) is a condition characterized by respiratory distress, altered mental status, and skin petechiae.
  • Clinical signs are evident hours to days after an injury involving long bone or pelvic fractures.
  • Marrowfat from the fracture site is believed to enter the pulmonary circulation, where it activates the coagulation cascade, causes platelet dysfunction, releases vasoactive substances and inflammatory cytokines, and causes subsequent neutrophil infiltration.
  • The treatment of FES is mostly supportive, but a meta-analysis by Bederman and colleagues has shown that the use of corticosteroids in patients with multiple long bone fractures reduces the rate of FES by 78% without significantly increasing the risk of complications related to the treatment of the fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the definitive diagnostic test for multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - CT scan is not sensitive for detecting multiple sclerosis lesions.

OPTION B - MRI with gadolinium is the gold standard for diagnosing multiple sclerosis as it identifies active demyelinating plaques.


OPTION C - Evoked potentials are supportive but not definitive.

OPTION D - CSF analysis (oligoclonal bands) is useful but not diagnostic alone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with an abnormal first trimester ultrasound showing a thickened nuchal translucency and an absence of nasal bone. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The combination of thickened nuchal translucency and absence of the nasal bone on first trimester screening is highly suggestive of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). This is an important marker in early screening for chromosomal abnormalities.

Option wise Explanation:

A) Down syndrome (Correct Answer):

  • Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is the most likely diagnosis given the findings of thickened nuchal translucency and absence of the nasal bone on first trimester ultrasound.
  • These are known markers for Down syndrome, which is a chromosomal abnormality caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21.
  • First trimester screening for Down syndrome typically includes measurements of nuchal translucency, and the absence of the nasal bone, along with other factors like maternal age, serum markers, and fetal anatomy.
  • Other ultrasound findings that may suggest Down syndrome include shortened femur length, echogenic bowel, and heart defects.

B) Turner syndrome:

  • Turner syndrome (45, X) is a chromosomal condition that affects females, characterized by the absence of one X chromosome.
  • The nuchal translucency is often thickened in Turner syndrome, but the absence of the nasal bone is not a specific feature.
  • Turner syndrome is typically diagnosed through karyotyping and often presents with other features like short stature, webbed neck, ovarian dysfunction, and heart defects.

C) Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18):

  • Edwards syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18.
  • While thickened nuchal translucency can be seen in Edwards syndrome, the absence of the nasal bone is not a typical finding.
  • Other features of Edwards syndrome include severe developmental delays, clenched hands, rocker-bottom feet, and heart defects.

D) Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13):

  • Patau syndrome involves an extra copy of chromosome 13 and is associated with severe intellectual disability and multiple congenital anomalies.
  • The absence of the nasal bone and thickened nuchal translucency can occasionally be seen, but these findings are less specific than in Down syndrome.
  • Other features of Patau syndrome include polydactyly, holoprosencephaly, and cleft lip/palate.

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 1, Prenatal Diagnosis of Chromosomal Abnormalities Page no. 3

They are often caused by excessive probing of an abscess cavity or fistula tract during examination under anesthesia. They are difficult to distinguish from high-level trans-sphincteric tracks; however, the management strategies are similar.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is not typically used for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS)?
questions.solution:
• A) Anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL): These antibodies are commonly used for the diagnosis of APS. Elevated levels of anticardiolipin antibodies are one of the diagnostic criteria for APS.
  • B) Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies (anti-β2GPI): Anti-β2GPI antibodies are another crucial marker used in the diagnosis of APS. Their presence, along with clinical symptoms, confirms the diagnosis.
  • C) Lupus anticoagulant (LA): The presence of lupus anticoagulant, identified through clotting tests, is a hallmark of APS. It is another key antibody for the diagnosis.
  • D) Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): ANA testing is primarily used to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is not specific to APS. Although some APS patients may test positive for ANA, it is not a diagnostic criterion for APS.

Therefore, ANA is not typically used for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS), which relies on anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL), anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies (anti-β2GPI), and lupus anticoagulant (LA).

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 17, Other Medical Disorders in Pregnancy, Page no. 292

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with AIDS presented to the clinic because of fever malaise, myalgias, nausea, and diarrhea. Three weeks earlier, the patient had started a highly active antiretroviral therapy. He stated that the symptoms were most prominent several hours after each dose and that they seemed to be getting progressively worse with each dose. Physical examination disclosed maculopapular rash over his face, trunk, and arms. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The patient was most likely suffering from a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir.
  • This is a multiorgan systemic illness that occurs in up to 8% of HIV-infected patients who initiate therapy with abacavir.
  • Abacavir hypersensitivity reaction can cause life-threatening complications if abacavir is continued despite progressive symptoms.
  • In addition, among persons who have experienced the abacavir hypersensitivity reaction, subsequent rechallenge with abacavir following discontinuation can cause an immediate and potentially fatal reaction.
  • Abacavir increases the risk of myocardial infarction.
  • It may cause severe hypersensitivity reaction particularly in patients having HLA B*5701 allele. Testing of this allele should be done before starting abacavir.

Option A: These drugs very rarely cause hypersensitivity reactions.

Option B & C: These drugs are not active against HIV.

Key takeaway

  • Abacavir cause severe hypersensitivity reaction particularly in patients having HLA B*5701 allele. Testing of this allele should be done before starting abacavir.

[Good to Know]

[Abacavir]

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to his physician complaining of dry mouth, constipation, and difficulty in urination. He also noticed an increase in appetite. The man had started a therapy with cyproheptadine 2 weeks earlier to treat cold induced urticaria. Drug-induced blockade of which of the following pairs of receptors most likely mediated the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Cyproheptadine is a first-generation H1 antagonist.
  • Like other drugs of this class, it can also block muscarinic and serotonergic receptors (mainly 5-HT2).
  • The blockade of M3 receptors explains the dry mouth, constipation, and dysuria, while the increase in appetite was likely due to blockade of 5-HT2 receptors in the hypothalamus.
  • In fact, cyproheptadine has been used to treat anorexia, with mixed results.

Cyproheptadine

  • It primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional
    • H1 antihistaminic
    • Anticholinergic
    • Sedative properties.
  • It increases appetite and has been used in children as well as in poor eaters to promote weight gain.
  • The blockade of M3 receptors explains the dry mouth, constipation, and dysuria, while the increase in appetite was likely due to blockade of 5-HT2 receptors in the hypothalamus.
  • The anti 5-HT activity of cyproheptadine has been utilized in controlling intestinal manifestations of carcinoid and postgastrectomy dumping syndromes, as well as in antagonizing priapism/orgasmic delay caused by 5-HT uptake inhibitors like fluoxetine and trazodone.
  • Side effects
    • Drowsiness
    • Dry mouth
    • Confusion
    • Ataxia
    • Weight gain
  • Key Takeaway:
    • Cyproheptadine primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional H1 antihistaminic, Anticholinergic and Sedative properties.

[Good to Know]

[Cyproheptadine]

questions.text: Which of the following fetal complications is most commonly associated with GDM?
questions.solution:
GDM can lead to polyhydramnios due to fetal hyperglycemia causing osmotic diuresis.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Microcephaly:

  • Microcephaly is not commonly associated with GDM.
  • It is more frequently linked to congenital infections (e.g., TORCH infections) or genetic disorders.

B) Polyhydramnios (Correct Answer):

  • GDM often leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which causes osmotic diuresis in the fetus, leading to an increase in amniotic fluid volume (polyhydramnios).
  • Polyhydramnios is one of the most common fetal complications of GDM.

C) Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR):

  • IUGR is less common in GDM unless there is coexisting vascular compromise (e.g., pregestational diabetes with vasculopathy).
  • More often, GDM results in macrosomia rather than IUGR.

D) Oligohydramnios:

  • Oligohydramnios is typically associated with placental insufficiency, post-term pregnancy, or fetal anomalies affecting the urinary system.
  • It is not a common complication of GDM.

Key takeaway: complications of GDM

For mother:

  • During pregnancy : hypertension, pre eclampsia,polyhydramnios
  • During labour: prolonged labour due to big baby, Shoulder dystocia, perineal Injury.
  • During puerperium : puerperal sepsis, lactational failure

For baby :

  • High glucose level - increased insulin - increases growth of baby
  • Still birth, Jaundice
  • Respiratory Distress:- Increased Insulin level - inhibit surfactant production - decreased lung maturity .
  • Neonatal hypoglycemia: after birth Glucose Transport stopped but insulin level still high causes hypoglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 15, Diabetes in Pregnancy, Page no. 260

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a therapeutic application of cryotherapy in ophthalmology?
questions.solution:
Cryotherapy in Ophthalmology

Cryopexy: Application of intense cold (-40°C to -100°C) using a cryoprobe to treat various ocular conditions.

Principle:

Cryotherapy works on the Joule-Thompson principle of cooling, which results in tissue injury by intense cold.

Cryo Unit:

  • Uses gases like freon, nitrous oxide, or carbon dioxide as cooling agents.
  • Cryoprobes come in various sizes, e.g., 1mm for intravitreal use, 1.5mm for cataract extraction, 2.5mm for retina, and 4mm for cyclocryopexy.

Modes of Action:

  • Tissue necrosis (e.g., in tumors, cyclocryopexy).
  • Adhesion production (e.g., between retina and choroid in retinal detachment).
  • Vascular occlusion (e.g., in Coats' disease).
  • Adherence of cryoprobe (e.g., during cataract extraction).

Uses:

  1. Lids:
    • Cryolysis for trichiasis
    • Cryotherapy for warts, Molluscum contagiosum, basal cell carcinoma, and haemangioma.
  2. Conjunctiva:
    • For hypertrophied papillae in vernal catarrh.
  3. Cornea:
    • Treats herpes simplex keratitis.
  4. Lens:
    • Used in cryoextraction for cataract surgery -ICCE (no longer common today).
  5. Ciliary Body:
    • Cyclocryopexy for absolute glaucoma and neovascular glaucoma.
  6. Retina:
    • Sealing retinal holes in retinal detachment.
    • Prophylactic cryopexy to prevent retinal detachment.
    • Anterior retinal cryopexy in ischemic retinal diseases.
    • Treatment of retinoblastoma and angiomas.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, AK Khurana, 6th Edition, page number 463

choices.text: Stool in amoebic dysentery is more likely to be bright red, while bacillary dysentery presents with dark red stool
The stool in amoebic dysentery is small quantities of stool, while bacillary dysentery is copious amount
