questions.text: Which of the following stool characteristics is most commonly associated with amoebic dysentery as compared to bacillary dysentery?
questions.solution:
Explanation of all 4 options:

Key Takeaways:

  • Stool consistency: In amoebic dysentery, stools are non-adherent to the container, while in bacillary dysentery, they tend to be adherent due to the presence of inflammatory exudates.
  • Blood appearance in stool: Bacillary dysentery usually results in bright red blood in the stool, while amoebic dysentery often produces dark red stool.
  • Cellular response: Bacillary dysentery is characterized by numerous pus cells, while amoebic dysentery typically shows few.
  • Macroscopic stool features: Amoebic dysentery often results in a larger volume of stool, whereas bacillary dysentery causes smaller, more frequent stools.

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.
  • It is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease in which blood vessels of the lower limb are severely damaged, eventually resulting in gangrene.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of arsenic, typically through contaminated drinking water or food, can lead to peripheral neuropathy and other health issues.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Lead: Lead poisoning can lead to developmental delays, learning difficulties, behavior problems, and impaired growth. In adults, it can cause neurological symptoms, such as headaches, memory loss, and concentration problems, as well as abdominal pain and reproductive It is not associated with black foot disease.

chronic lead poisoning mnemonic : ABCDEFGH

Anemia

Basophilic stippling

Burtoning gingival lines

Colic abdominal pain, Constipation

Drop - wrist / foot

Encephalopathy

Facial pallor

Growth retardation

Hyperuricemia- saturnine gout

  • Option C - Mercury: The symptoms and effects of mercury poisoning depend on the form of mercury involved:
    • Methylmercury, a form of organic mercury found in contaminated fish and seafood, primarily affects the nervous system and can cause developmental issues in children, as well as neurological and cardiovascular problems in adults.
    • Neurological disorder: erethism / erethismus mercurialis/mad hatter disease.
    • Acrodynia / pink disease: pain and pink discolouration in the hands and feet
    • It is not associated with black foot disease.
  • Option D - Cadmium: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, causes Itai Itai disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 538

questions.text: A 65 year old patient was scheduled for surgery to remove a glioma located on his left parietal lobe. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriately given before and after surgery to prevent increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
• Osmotic diuretics are often given to patients with a brain tumor before and after neurosurgery to reduce cerebrospinal fluid volume and therefore intracranial pressure.
  • These drugs cannot cross the blood−brain barrier, and they enhance the diffusion of water back into the plasma by elevating plasma osmolality.
  • Mannitol is a low molecular weight compound used i.v. for the treatment of glaucoma and cerebral edema (drug of choice).

Osmotic Diuretics

  • They are inert drugs that can cause osmotic diuresis.
  • Mnemonic [MIGU]
    • Mannitol,
    • Isosorbide
    • Glycerol,
    • Urea and

It is filtered at the glomerulus and reaches the proximal tubule (PT) and loop of Henle → Loop of Henle, is the major site of action of these diuretics. → When administered IV, mannitol increases the osmotic pressure in the blood vessels → Followed by removal of excess fluid from the cells results in the expansion of extracellular fluid volume. → Consequently, renal blood flow and GFR increases.

Option B & C: Other diuretics are useless in decreasing intracranial pressure.

Option D: Increased intracranial pressure often causes hypertension and bradycardia. Drugs that decrease the heart rate are therefore contraindicated.

  • Key takeaway
    • Osmotic diuretics are often given to patients with a brain tumor before and after neurosurgery to reduce cerebrospinal fluid volume and therefore intracranial pressure.

[Must Know]

[Mannitol]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 63

questions.text: Eustachian tube gets blocked if there is a pressure difference of (b/w nasopharynxa & middle ear)?
questions.solution:
The Eustachian tube is a tube that connects the middle ear to the throat and nasal-sinus cavity. It has several physiological functions, including:

Equalizing air pressure

The Eustachian tube equalizes the air pressure in the middle ear with the air pressure in the atmosphere. This allows the eardrum to vibrate properly and transmit sound. When the Eustachian tube opens, you might hear a 'popping' sound. The eustachian tubes closes when the pressure difference between the nasopharynx and middle ear becomes more than 90 mm of H2O.

Draining fluid

The Eustachian tube helps drain fluid from the middle ear. Mucosal folds in the Eustachian tube work with surface cilia to move secretions from the middle ear to the nasopharynx.

Protecting from sound pressures and secretions

The Eustachian tube protects the middle ear from nasopharyngeal sound pressures and secretions.

Oxygenating the middle ear

The Eustachian tube allows air to exchange in the middle ear, which replenishes oxygen.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 68.

questions.text: A 42 year old man was admitted to the emergency department in acute distress with breathlessness, markedly distended neck veins, and atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure was 100/90 mm Hg, pulse 120 bpm. An echocardiogram revealed an ejection fraction of 35%. Treatment was started with furosemide, captopril, and digoxin. In this patient, digoxin most likely decreased which of the following cardiovascular parameters?
questions.solution:
• An inotropic drug increases the force of heart contraction; therefore, a higher fraction of the end-diastolic volume is ejected during systole.
  • Digoxin effects over Heart
  • Digoxin has direct effects on myocardial contractility and electrophysiological properties.
  • In addition, it has vagomimetic action, reflex effects due to alteration in haemodynamics and direct CNS effects altering sympathetic activity.
  • Force of contraction
  • Digoxin causes a dose dependent increase in force of contraction of heart-a positive inotropic action.
  • This is especially seen in the failing heart which is exquisitely sensitive. Systole is shortened, diastole is prolonged.
  • The digitalized failing heart regains some of its capacity to contract more forcefully when subjected to increased resistance to ejection.
  • There is more complete emptying of failing and dilated ventricles, cardiac output is increased and end-diastolic volume is reduced.

Option A: All inotropic drugs increase, not decrease, the stroke volume.

Option C: Digoxin increases, not decreases, the systolic blood pressure in patients in cardiac failure because of the increase in cardiac output .

Option D: By increasing cardiac contractility, digoxin increases the stroke volume and offsets the reactive, sympathetically mediated vasoconstriction. Therefore, the pulse pressure is increased, not decreased

  • Key takeaway
    • Digoxin causes a dose dependent increase in force of contraction of heart-a positive inotropic action. There is more complete emptying of failing and dilated ventricles, cardiac output is increased and end-diastolic volume is reduced.

[Good to Know]

[Digoxin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 556-557

choices.text: Tight casts are a common cause of compartment syndrome
Pulselessness is an extremely late sign
Compartment syndrome can occur in open fractures
The incidence of compartment syndrome associated with high- and low-energy injuries is nearly equal

questions.text: All are true regarding compartment Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Option A: (False)

Compartment syndrome is raised pressure in a fascial compartment to a level that compromises tissue perfusion.

There are several causes of compartment syndrome, fractures being the most common (70%), followed by soft-tissue contusions (23%).

Rarer causes include bleeding disorders, including anticoagulation; burns (particularly circumferential third-degree burns); post-ischaemic swelling (reperfusion injury); tight casts/ dressings; and extravasation of intravenous infusions (contrast under pressure).

Option B: (True)

Compartment syndrome is a clinical diagnosis characterised by pain out of proportion, increasing pain, and pain on passive stretch, with paraesthesia possible. Paralysis, numbness, and pallor are late signs and pulselessness is an extremely late sign

Options C & D: (True)

There are some common pitfalls to remember. The incidence of compartment syndrome associated with high- and low-energy injuries is nearly equal. Compartment syndrome can occur in open fractures. Have a high index of suspicion and be particularly vigilant in patients with an altered level of consciousness

Key Takeaway Point:


Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Chapter 32, Page 444/459

questions.text: A 25-year-old healthy male volunteer received an intravenous infusion of a new drug in a phase 1 clinical trial. It was found that the drug causes an increase in cardiac contractility, a slight increase in heart rate, and no major changes or a decrease in systemic vascular resistance. Which of the following drugs does the new agent most resemble?
questions.solution:
• Dobutamine is a selective β agonist that activates mainly β1 receptors.
  • This should cause an increase of all the parameters of heart activity, but for unknown reasons, frequency and automaticity are increased only slightly.
  • Dobutamine
    • A derivative of DA, but not a D1 or D2 receptor agonist.
    • Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist.
    • The only prominent action of clinically employed doses (2-8 μg/kg/min i.v. infusion) is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.
    • Compared to isoprenaline, increase in heart rate is less marked.
    • As such, it is considered to be a relatively selective β1 agonist.
    • Dobutamine is used as an inotropic agent in pump failure accompanying myocardial infarction, cardiac surgery, and for short term management of severe congestive heart failure.
    • β1 receptors present in heart and kidney,
    • β2 receptors present in blood Vessels, bronchi,pancreas, skeletal muscle
    • β3 receptors Present in urinary bladder

Option A, C & D: All of these drugs cause substantial changes in heart rate and systemic vascular resistance.

  • Key takeaway
    • Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist. The only prominent action is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.

[Must Know]

[Dobutamine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 147

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman suffering from chronic asthma was admitted to the hospital with nausea and vomiting, extreme restlessness, insomnia, tremor, mental confusion and fever. After her sister died a few days ago, she experienced increased hunger, dyspnea on exertion, palpitations,and diarrhea. Laboratory data on admission included a free thyroxine (FT4) level of 11 ng/dL and undetectable thyroid-stimulating hormone levels. Which of the following drugs should be included in the emergency treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
• The signs and symptoms of the patient and the lab exams indicate that she is suffering from thyroid storm, a life-threatening syndrome characterized by the abrupt onset of the more florid symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
  • An emergency treatment is mandatory and usually includes propranolol to control hypertension and tachycardia.
  • When propranolol is contraindicated, as in this case (asthma), calcium channel blockers with cardiac activity (diltiazem or verapamil) can be used.
  • Thyroid storm (thyrotoxic crisis):
    • This is an emergency due to decompensated hyperthyroidism.
  • Vigorous treatment with the following is indicated:
    • Nonselective β blockers (e.g. propranolol) are the most valuable measure. They afford dramatic symptomatic relief.
    • In addition, higher doses reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
    • Propranolol to control severe cardiovascular manifestations.
    • Calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are used if b-blockers are contra-indicated as in asthmatics.
    • Iodides (NaI, KI, Lugol's iodine) to inhibit the release of thyroid hormones from the gland.
    • Propylthiouracil or methimazole to reduce the synthesis of thyroid hormones.
    • Hydrocortisone to protect the patient against shock.
    • Rehydration, anxiolytics, external cooling and appropriate antibiotics are the other measures.

Option B: Radioactive iodine can be used for the long-term management of the disease but is not a drug for the emergency treatment of thyroid storm.

Option C: Not to be given in thyroid storm

Option D: Propranolol is contraindicated, as in this case, calcium channel blockers with cardiac activity (diltiazem or verapamil) can be used.

  • Key takeaway
    • In thyroid storm an emergency treatment is mandatory and usually includes propranolol to control hypertension and tachycardia.
    • When propranolol is contraindicated, as in this case, calcium channel blockers with cardiac activity (diltiazem or verapamil) can be used.

[Must Know]

[Diltiazem]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 278-279

questions.text: Which of the following is the 'Least common' complication of measles?
questions.solution:
MEASLES (RUBEOLA):

  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days
  • Causative agent: RNA paramyxovirus (so for only one serotype known)
  • Source of Infection: cases (carriers are not known to occur)
  • Period of Communicability: 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash (Rash: Retro-auricular origin)
  • Measles has no second attacks (lifelong immunity seen)
  • Secondary attack rate of Measles: 80%
  • Measles shows a cyclical trend: Increase every 2-3 years
  • Blood cell type predominantly infected in Measles: Monocyte
  • Pathognomic clinical feature of Measles: Koplik spots (on buccal mucosa opposite upper 2nd molar)
  • Pathognomic microscopic feature of Measles: Warthin Finkledy cells (multinucleated giant cells)
  • MC complication of measles in young children: Otitis media
  • SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis) is a rare complication of measles: 7 per million cases of Measles (7-10 years after initial infection)
  • Epidemic of measles occur: If proportion of susceptible children is >40%
  • If Measles is introduced in a virgin community: it infects >90% children
  • Eradication of Measles: Requires a vaccination coverage >96%
  • Baby measles (Exanthem subitum-roseola infantum): Sixth disease (three-day fever)
  • German Measles: Rubella

Reference: Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 5, Page No. 164

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) presents with tense ascites and no hepatic encephalopathy. Lab results: bilirubin 5 mg/dL, albumin 2.8 g/dL, INR 2.0. Using the Modified CTP score for PSC, calculate the patient's score.
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway Point:

The three most common objective measures of surgical risk in cirrhotic patients are the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, the MELD score, and residual liver volume.

The Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension and subsequently is useful in predicting surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations on cirrhotic patients.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Ed - Page 198

questions.text: A 47 year old man recently diagnosed with exertional angina started treatment with sublingual nitroglycerin, as needed and oral isosorbide mononitrate. Which of the following is a potential detrimental effect of nitrates in the prophylactic treatment of exertional angina?
questions.solution:
By causing peripheral vasodilation, high doses of nitrates can induce reflex tachycardia, which in turn increases oxygen consumption.

This detrimental effect can be prevented by the concomitant use of a β-blocker.

  • Different nitrates
    • Glyceryl Trinitrate / Nitroglycerine [GTN/ NTG]
    • Isosorbide Dinitrate [IDN]
    • Isosorbide Mononitrate [IMN]
    • Penta Erythrital Tetra Nitrate [PETN]
    • Amyl Nitrite [AN]
  • Nitrates should not be given with Sildenafil
    [Risk of Severe hypotension]
  • Adverse effects These are mostly due to vasodilatation.

Mnemonic [MRF]

Methemoglobinemia

Rashes are rare (common with pentaerythritol tetranitrate)

Fullness in head, throbbing headache;

Flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting; these are due to postural hypotension

Option A & C: These are all useful effects of nitrates in exertional angina.

Option D: Nitrates tend to decrease, not increase, ventricular enddiastolic volume.

  • Key takeaway
  • Nitrates can cause reflex tachycardia and reflex increase in cardiac contractility, but these are detrimental, not therapeutic, effects in patients with angina.

[Good to Know]

[Isosorbide mononitrate]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 587-588

choices.text: Atrophy of pancreatic acini with normal islet morphology
Increase in the number of islets of Langerhans
Fibrosis and atrophy of islets of Langerhans with amyloid deposition

questions.text: Which of the following morphological alterations is commonly observed in the pancreas of individuals with long-standing diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
A) Atrophy of pancreatic acini with normal islet morphology is incorrect because while acinar atrophy can occur in diabetes, there are also significant changes in the islets, including amyloid deposition and fibrosis, rather than just normal morphology.

B) Increase in the number of islets of Langerhans.

  • Diabetes, especially type 2, is typically associated with islet dysfunction rather than an increase in the number of islets.
  • There may be hyperplasia early in the disease as a compensatory response to insulin resistance, but this is not typically observed in long-standing diabetes.

C) Long-standing diabetes mellitus, especially in type 2 diabetes, is associated with degeneration of the islets of Langerhans.

  • This can lead to atrophy of the islets, with an accumulation of amyloid deposits within the islets. These amyloid deposits disrupt normal islet function and are a hallmark of diabetic pancreas pathology, especially in type 2 diabetes.
  • Fibrosis in the pancreatic tissue is also common, as the chronic high glucose levels and metabolic changes can lead to collagen deposition in the stroma.

D) Hyperplasia of ductal epithelium is not a characteristic finding in diabetes mellitus. Ductal epithelium may show some changes due to chronic inflammation or other factors, but ductal hyperplasia is not a hallmark of diabetic pancreatic pathology.

Key takeaways:

Here are some pancreatic alterations that can occur in diabetes patients:

Type 1 Diabetes

  1. Insulitis: Inflammation of the islets of Langerhans, leading to the destruction of beta cells.
  2. Beta-cell destruction: Autoimmune destruction of beta cells, leading to a decrease in insulin production.
  3. Islet cell atrophy: Atrophy of the islets of Langerhans, leading to a decrease in insulin production.

Type 2 Diabetes

  1. Amyloid deposition: Deposition of amyloid fibrils in the islets of Langerhans, leading to the destruction of beta cells.
  2. Beta-cell dysfunction: Dysfunction of beta cells, leading to a decrease in insulin production and secretion.
  3. Islet cell hypertrophy: Hypertrophy of the islets of Langerhans, leading to an increase in insulin production.
  4. Pancreatic fibrosis: Fibrosis of the pancreas, leading to a decrease in pancreatic function.

Common Alterations

  1. Pancreatic atrophy: Atrophy of the pancreas, leading to a decrease in pancreatic function.
  2. Islet cell exhaustion: Exhaustion of the islets of Langerhans, leading to a decrease in insulin production.
  3. Ductal proliferation: Proliferation of the pancreatic ducts, leading to an increase in pancreatic juice production.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th Edition, Page No. 1108-09.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has complained of headaches for the past week. His gait has become ataxic. After sudden onset of vomiting, he is brought to the emergency department, where he becomes comatose. On physical examination, he is afebrile. A lumbar puncture is done and cytologic examination of the CSF shows anaplastic cells with dark blue nuclei and scant cytoplasm. An MRI is most likely to show a mass in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation and cytologic examination of the CSF are consistent with a diagnosis of medulloblastoma.

A) Centrum semiovale is a location typically associated with glioblastoma.

B) Medulloblastoma typically arises from the cerebellar vermis.

Age: Medulloblastoma typically occurs in children between the ages of 4 and 10.

Symptoms: Headaches, vomiting, and ataxia are common presenting symptoms.

CSF cytology: Anaplastic cells with dark blue nuclei and scant cytoplasm are characteristic of medulloblastoma.

C) Cranial nerve VIII is a location typically associated with acoustic neuroma.

D) Fourth ventricle is a location that can be involved by various tumors, including ependymoma and choroid plexus papilloma.

Key Takeaway:

Medulloblastoma is a highly malignant brain tumor that arises from the cerebellar vermis, typically in children, and is characterized by anaplastic cells on CSF cytology.

MGG staining, magnification 400x, showing cells of medulloblastoma in cerebrospinal fluid.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th Edition, Page No. 1298.

questions.text: Which trematode is known to cause liver infection, transmitted by ingestion of metacercariae larvae from fish?
questions.solution:
• Clonorchis spp. (Chinese liver fluke) infects the bile ducts of the liver. The larvae are transmitted through ingestion of metacercaria larvae from fish.
  • Operculated eggs are diagnostic.
  • Schistosoma spp -- snail -- human
  • Fasciola hepatica -- snail --- aquatic plant --- human (infect the liver)
  • Paragonimus spp --- snail --- crab --- human (infect the lung )

Key Points:

  • Clonorchis spp. → Liver → Fish → Ingestion of metacercaria larvae
  • Operculated eggs

Reference:

  • Clonorchiasis (WHO, 2020)

questions.text: Which of the following is the Correctly matched pair of heavy metals and their chelating agents?
questions.solution:
Penicillamine

  • It is dimethyl cysteine, obtained as a degradation product of penicillin.
  • It was found to have strong copper chelating property and was used in 1956 for Wilson's disease. It selectively chelates Cu, Hg, Pb and Zn.
  • The d-isomer is used therapeutically, because the l-isomer and the recemate produce optic neuritis and are more toxic.
  • It is adequately absorbed after oral administration, little metabolized in the body and excreted in urine and faeces. When given to patients with heavy metal toxicity, excretion of the metal is enhanced.
  • Wilson's disease (Hepatolenticular degeneration): This is due to genetic deficiency of ceruloplasmin, a protein which normally binds and disposes off Cu from the body. In its absence, plasma concentration of free Cu is high which gets deposited in liver, substantia nigra, basal ganglia of brain, and causes local degeneration.

Penicillamine Uses

  1. Wilson's disease (Hepatolenticular degeneration)
  2. Copper or mercury poisoning:
    It is the drug of choice for Cu poisoning and alternative drug to dimercaprol/ succimer for Hg poisoning.
  3. Chronic lead poisoning:
    It may be used as an adjuvant to CaNa2EDTA, but succimer is preferred.
  4. Cystinuria and cystine stones:
    It promotes the excretion of cysteine and prevents its Precipitation in the urinary tract, because penicillamine-cysteine complex is more soluble than dicysteine (cystine).
  5. Scleroderma:
    Penicillamine benefits by increasing soluble collagen.

CHELATING AGENTS

Key takeaway

  • Penicillamine have strong copper chelating property and was used in Wilson's disease. It selectively chelates Cu, Hg, Pb and Zn.
  • The d-isomer is used therapeutically, when given to patients with heavy metal toxicity, excretion of the metal is enhanced.

[Good to Know]

[Penicillamine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 966

questions.text: Osborn wave in ECG is found in?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - No characteristic ECG finding.

OPTION B - Osborn wave is characteristic in hypothermia

OPTION C - Marked QT prolongation, sometimes with deep, wide T-wave inversions, may occur with intracranial bleeds, particularly subarachnoid hemorrhage ("CVA T-wave" pattern)

OPTION D - Right axis deviation is seen in ECG

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Systemic hypothermia also prolongs repolarization, usually with a distinctive convex elevation or "hump" at the J point referred to as Osborn wave. It is due to altered ventricular action potential characteristics.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, chapter 240, page 1831

choices.text: Secretes high levels of inhibin, leading to suppressed FSH
Exclusively produces estrogen without any hormonal feedback
Generates random hormone levels with no predictable pattern

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal vaginal bleeding and an ovarian mass. Pathology reveals a granulosa cell tumor. Which of the following statements best characterizes the hormonal profile of this tumor?
questions.solution:
A) Produces excessive testosterone, causing virilization

  • While some androgen production can occur, granulosa cell tumors are primarily estrogen-producing
  • Virilization is not a characteristic feature
  • Reasoning: Misunderstands the primary hormonal secretion pattern

B) Secretes high levels of inhibin, leading to suppressed FSH

  • Granulosa cell tumors characteristically produce high levels of inhibin-B
  • Inhibin selectively suppresses follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  • Mechanism:
    • Inhibin acts on the pituitary gland
    • Blocks FSH production through negative feedback
    • Creates a distinctive hormonal signature
  • Clinical Implications:
    • Can be used as a tumor marker
    • Helps in diagnosis and monitoring

C) Exclusively produces estrogen without any hormonal feedback - Estrogen production occurs, but not in isolation

  • Tumor has complex hormonal interactions
  • Inhibin plays a crucial role in hormonal regulation
  • Reasoning: Oversimplifies hormonal dynamics

D) Generates random hormone levels with no predictable pattern - Granulosa cell tumors have a predictable hormonal profile

  • Characterized by consistent estrogen and inhibin production
  • Reasoning: Misrepresents the tumor's hormonal characteristics

Advanced Pathophysiological Insights:

  • Granulosa cell tumors arise from ovarian granulosa cells
  • Typically low-grade malignant potential
  • Hormonally active tumors with predictable secretion patterns

Key Takeaways:

  1. Granulosa cell tumors primarily produce estrogen and inhibin
  2. Inhibin suppresses FSH through negative feedback
  3. Hormonal markers are crucial for diagnosis and monitoring

Clinical Correlations:

  • Can cause precocious puberty in young patients
  • Potential cause of postmenopausal bleeding
  • Useful tumor marker: Inhibin B levels

Diagnostic Considerations:

  • Serum estrogen levels elevated
  • Inhibin B as a specific tumor marker
  • Imaging studies to assess tumor extent

Molecular Mechanism:

  • FOXL2 gene mutations common
  • Impacts cell proliferation and hormonal regulation

Reference: Robbins & cotran, 10th edition, page no. 1026.

questions.text: A 45 year old scientist working in private laboratory has developed a drug that is described as: "A drug that binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site and alters the affinity of the receptor for the endogenous ligand'. Which of the following option is most suitable for the same?
questions.solution:
• Allosteric modulators shows high selectivity for distinct receptor subtypes
    These agents exert their pharmacological actions by altering the affinity or efficacy of orthosteric muscarinic ligands.
  • Positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) enhance orthosteric activity, while negative allosteric modulators (NAMs) inhibit it.
  • Allosteric agents that can directly activate muscarinic receptors are termed allosteric agonists.
  • A noncompetitive antagonist binds to the receptor at a site other than the agonist-binding site and renders it less effective by preventing agonist binding or preventing activation.

Noncompetitive antagonism

  • The antagonist is chemically unrelated to the agonist, binds to a different allosteric site altering the receptor in such a way that it is unable to combine with the agonist or is unable to transduce the response.
  • This is also called allosteric antagonism. Because the agonist and the antagonist are combining with different sites, there is no competition between them-even high agonist concentration is unable to reverse the block completely.
  • Increasing concentrations of the antagonist progressively flatten the agonist DRC

Option A: Competitive antagonism

The antagonist is chemically similar to the agonist, competes with it and binds to the same site of the agonist molecules. Because the antagonist has affinity but no intrinsic activity, no response is produced and the log DRC of the agonist is shifted to the right.

Option B: Inverse agonist

These type of drugs bind to the receptor and produce opposite effect (IA is negative) e.g. b carboline is an inverse agonist at BZD receptors.

Option C: Partial agonist

It activates the receptor submaximally (IA between 0 and +1). It will produce the similar effect in the absence of agonist but it will decrease the effect of a pure agonist.

Key Takeaway

  • Allosteric modulators shows high selectivity for distinct receptor subtypes. These agents exert their pharmacological actions by altering the affinity or efficacy of orthosteric muscarinic ligands.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 68-69

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue, dry mouth, and joint pain. On examination, she has parotid gland enlargement and dry oral mucosa. Laboratory tests reveal positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus can present with fatigue and joint pain, but parotid enlargement and dry mouth are not typical features.
  • Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis causes joint pain but does not lead to parotid enlargement or positive anti-SSA antibodies.
  • Option C: Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, parotid gland enlargement, and positive anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies.
  • Option D: Scleroderma primarily presents with skin changes, not parotid enlargement or dry mouth.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, and parotid gland enlargement with positive anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 361, page 2788

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location for pressure sore development?
questions.solution:
The sacrum (28%-36%) is the most common area in which pressure sores develop, followed by the heel (23%-30%) and the ischium (17%-20%).

Key Takeaway Points:

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Ed -Page 1938
Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 35

questions.text: In a cohort study, the participants are grouped based on:
questions.solution:
Cohort study is a type of analytical study which is usually undertaken to obtain additional evidence to refute or support the existence of an association between suspected cause and disease. Cohort study is known by variety of name: prospective study, longitudinal study, incidence study and forward-looking study.

The distinguishing features of cohort studies are:

  1. The cohorts are identified prior to the appearance of the disease under investigation
  2. The study groups, so defined, are observed over a period of time to determine the frequency of disease among them
  3. The study proceeds forward from cause to effect

Reference:- Park’s Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 3, Page No. 83

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of irregular periods presents with weight gain, hirsutism, and acne. On examination, she has bilateral ovarian enlargement with multiple small cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, acne, and bilateral ovarian enlargement with multiple cysts on ultrasound. It is also associated with insulin resistance and anovulation.

OPTION B - Ovarian cancer usually presents with abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, and ascites, not with cystic ovaries and hormonal imbalance.

OPTION C - Endometriosis presents with pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea, not typically with the hormonal features seen in this case.

OPTION D - Hyperprolactinemia can cause amenorrhea and galactorrhea, but it does not cause hirsutism and ovarian cysts as seen in this case.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. PCOS is a common cause of anovulation and hormonal imbalance in young women.
  2. Treatment focuses on menstrual regulation, cosmetic concerns (e.g., hirsutism), and insulin resistance.

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 392 PAGE 3029

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with her fourth episode of dizziness, sweating, and fatigue. Her blood glucose level is recorded at 40 mg/dL, and her symptoms improve rapidly after glucose administration. Similar episodes occurred in the past, with glucose levels of 37 and 43 mg/dL, respectively, each resolving with glucose treatment. The hospitalist refers her for further evaluation due to suspicion of insulinoma. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Option C: The fasting test is the gold standard for diagnosing insulinoma. It measures glucose, insulin, and C-peptide levels during fasting to confirm insulinoma.

Option A: Proinsulin is often elevated in insulinoma, but it's not the first diagnostic test. Option B: The OGTT is used for diabetes diagnosis, not insulinoma.

Option D: C-peptide levels are elevated in insulinoma but are part of the supervised fasting test. It is not the first test to do by itself.

Key Takeaway Message:

The cornerstone of diagnosis remains Whipple's triad:

  • symptoms induced by fasting;
  • hypoglycemia at the time of symptoms;
  • symptoms relieved by administration of glucose.

The key test is a 72-hour fast looking for documented endogenous hyperinsulinism associated with symptoms and signs of low plasma glucose (<3.0 mmol/L), elevated insulin, and high C-peptide.

If the test is negative and the suspicion of insulinoma is high, a prolonged oral glucose tolerance test is done.

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed -Page 906

questions.text: What is the typical treatment regimen for Trichuris trichiura infection?
questions.solution:
• The first-line treatment for Trichuris trichiura infection is Mebendazole 500 mg once, which is safe and effective for treating the infection. Albendazole is also used, but Mebendazole is more commonly recommended for a single-dose regimen.
  • Cure rates for both medications range from 70-90%.

Key Points:

  • Mebendazole 500 mg once or Albendazole for 3 days
  • Cure rates of 70-90%
  • Ivermectin is less effective for Trichuris infections

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 46 PP459

choices.text: Surgical procedures designed to improve absorptive capacity have shown some promise in managing adults but not in children
Short bowel syndrome usually appears when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel
All patients with less than 100 cm of small intestine ending in a stoma will require long-term parenteral nutrition
The mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome remains home parenteral nutrition (HPN).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding short bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Surgical procedures designed to improve the surface area or reduce the speed of transit of the remaining small intestine (and thus improve absorptive capacity) have shown some promise in children, but their place in managing adults with established short bowel syndrome currently remains unclear.

Option B: Features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel, the length and nature of the remaining intestine are also important.

Option C: Some (but not all) patients with 50-100 cm of small intestine and an intact colon will have intestinal failure, as will almost all patients with 50 cm or less of jejunum anastomosed to an intact colon. In contrast, most patients with less than 200 cm and virtually all with less than 100 cm of small intestine ending in a stoma will have intestinal failure and will require long-term parenteral nutrition.

Option D: Although there has also been interest in the use of drugs to promote intestinal adaptation, such as growth hormone, glutamine, and, most recently, glucagon-like peptide 2 agonists, the mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome remains home parenteral nutrition (HPN).

Key Takeaway Message:

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 1316

questions.text: 20-year-old man steps into an elevator full of people with influenza who are coughing and sneezing. The influenza viral particles that he inhales attach to respiratory epithelium, and viral infection reduces MHC class I molecules displayed on these epithelial cells. Which of the following immune cells is most likely to rapidly destroy the virally infected cells?
questions.solution:
A) CD4+ cells: They are not directly involved in recognizing and destroying infected cells. Instead, CD4+ cells are helper T cells that assist other cells,such as NK cells, macrophages, and B cells, in the immune response.

B) Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells aid in antigen presentation.

C) Macrophages: They are phagocytic cells that play a role in recognizing and engulfing pathogens, but they are not as effective as NK cells in recognizing and destroying virally infected cells.

D) Natural killer cell: Natural killer (NK) cells have the ability to respond without prior sensitization. They carry receptors for MHC class I molecules, which inhibit their lytic function.

  • When surface by viral interference, the inhibitory receptors on NK cells do not receive a negative signal, and the targeted cell is killed.
  • NK cells are often the first line of defense against viral infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of innate immune cell that plays a key role in recognizing and destroying virally infected cells and tumor cells.
  • NK cells are able to recognize infected cells that have reduced or absent MHC class I molecule expression, which is a common mechanism used by viruses to evade the immune system.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 198.

questions.text: Which genetic mutation is strongly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

A) TP53:

  • TP53 mutations are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which increases the risk of various cancers, including breast cancer, but it is not as strongly linked to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome as BRCA1/BRCA2.

B) BRCA1/BRCA2 (Correct Answer):

  • BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations are the most common genetic mutations associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
  • Women with BRCA1 mutations have a significantly increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, with lifetime risks of breast cancer up to 70% and ovarian cancer up to 40%.
  • BRCA2 mutations also carry high risks for both types of cancer, albeit somewhat lower than BRCA1.
  • These mutations are the cornerstone for the diagnosis and management of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

C) KRAS:

  • KRAS mutations are commonly found in various cancers such as lung, colon, and pancreatic cancers, but they are not specifically associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

D) APC:

  • APC mutations are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which predisposes individuals to colorectal cancer, but not breast or ovarian cancer.

Reference: National Cancer Institute. BRCA1 and BRCA2: Cancer Risk and Genetic Testing.

choices.text: S. dysenteriae type 1 produces Shiga toxin, which is responsible for the severe complications seen in shigellosis.
Shigella is highly infectious, with a low infective dose of as few as 10-100 bacilli capable of causing disease.
The primary mode of transmission for Shigella is through aerosolized droplets in crowded areas.
S. flexneri is the most common causative agent of shigellosis in developing countries, such as India.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Shigella infections is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The primary mode of transmission of Shigella is via the fecal-oral route, commonly through contaminated food, water, or direct contact with fecal material. Transmission through aerosolized droplets is incorrect in this context.

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 41 PP 405.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient recently traveled to a region experiencing an Ebola outbreak. He develops fever, vomiting, diarrhea, and hemorrhagic symptoms within 5 days of exposure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• (A) Malaria: While malaria can present with fever and flu-like symptoms, it does not cause hemorrhagic symptoms or the rapid onset seen with Ebola.
  • (B) Ebola virus infection: This is characterized by fever, vomiting, diarrhea, hemorrhagic symptoms, and a history of exposure to an endemic area. It is highly contagious and deadly, with a high fatality rate.
  • (C) Dengue fever: Dengue fever presents with fever, rash, and severe muscle pain but not hemorrhagic symptoms like those seen in Ebola.
  • (D) Yellow fever: Yellow fever also presents with fever and hemorrhagic symptoms but has a characteristic history of mosquito exposure and is less likely in this setting compared to Ebola.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ebola virus is a highly contagious hemorrhagic fever, especially common in regions with known outbreaks.
  • Early supportive care and isolation are crucial for controlling its spread.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for Ebola

questions.text: What is the initial treatment of choice for an acute gout attack?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Allopurinol is used for long-term urate-lowering therapy, not acute attacks.

OPTION B - Febuxostat, like allopurinol, is for chronic urate management and is not suitable for acute attacks.

OPTION C - Colchicine effectively reduces inflammation during acute gout attacks. It is most effective when started within the first 24 hours of symptom onset.

OPTION D - Probenecid is a uricosuric agent and not recommended for acute gout.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Acute gout is best managed with NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids.
  2. Avoid urate-lowering therapy initiation during an acute attack as it may exacerbate symptoms.
  3. Lifestyle modifications (e.g., reduced purine intake) complement pharmacologic therapy.

Reference: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 372 PAGE 2864

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea. On investigations, the Enterohemorrhagic strain of E. coli was isolated. On which of the following media can this organism be cultured?
questions.solution:
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) causes bloody diarrhea and is best cultured on Sorbitol MacConkey agar, which helps differentiate this pathogen from other E. coli strains. EHEC typically does not ferment sorbitol, which results in colorless colonies on Sorbitol MacConkey agar, whereas most non-pathogenic E. coli strains ferment sorbitol and produce pink colonies.
Other media mentioned, such as TCBS and Selenite F broth, Robertson cooked meat media are used for the isolation of different organisms (e.g., Vibrio cholerae and Salmonella and anaerobic bacteria respectively), not E. coli.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with hemoptysis, weight loss, and right shoulder pain. A chest X-ray reveals a mass in the apex of the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Small cell lung cancer is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes but not typically apex masses causing shoulder pain.

OPTION B - Squamous cell carcinoma commonly arises in the central airways but does not explain the specific symptoms of a Pancoast tumor.

OPTION C - Pancoast tumors are apical lung cancers that cause shoulder pain, Horner syndrome, and brachial plexus involvement.

OPTION D - Adenocarcinoma is the most common lung cancer but less commonly presents with apical involvement.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Pancoast tumors often lead to superior vena cava syndrome or Horner syndrome.
  2. Management involves chemoradiation followed by surgical resection.
  3. Imaging with CT/MRI helps delineate tumor extent.

Reference: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 78 PAGE 636

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Morphine:
    Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.
  • Option B - Cannabis:
    Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.
  • Option D - Alcohol:
    Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 598

questions.text: Which fetal vessel carries the highest oxygen concentration?
questions.solution:
A. Umbilical artery:

  • The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygen exchange.
  • Oxygen concentration is relatively low.

B. Umbilical vein (Correct Answer):

  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • This vessel has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation, delivering oxygen and nutrients to the fetus.

C. Ductus arteriosus:

  • The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, shunting blood away from the lungs.
  • Blood in this vessel is mixed, with a lower oxygen concentration than the umbilical vein.

D. Pulmonary artery:

  • In the fetus, the pulmonary artery carries blood from the right ventricle to the lungs, but due to the shunting of blood through the ductus arteriosus, the oxygen concentration remains low.

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG). Guidelines on Fetal Physiology and Development.

Severe headache with normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of subacute meningitis caused by tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Chronic meningitis due to tuberculosis typically has a slow, insidious onset, not rapid.
  • Option B: Tubercular meningitis often shows a lymphocytic predominance, not neutrophils.
  • Option C: The hallmark of tubercular meningitis is granulomatous inflammation.
  • Option D: CSF analysis is typically abnormal in tubercular meningitis, showing elevated protein, low glucose, and a lymphocytic predominance.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Tubercular meningitis presents insidiously with a granulomatous inflammation on biopsy. The combination of unrelenting headache, stiff neck, fatigue, night sweats, and fever with a CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis and a mildly decreased glucose concentration is highly suspicious for tuberculous meningitis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 138, page 1109

questions.text: Framingham Heart Study is an example of:
questions.solution:
FRAMINGHAM HEART STUDY:

  • Is a classic example of cohort study
  • Initiated in 1948 by US Public Health Service at Framingham, a town in Massachusetts, USA
  • Aim: To study the relationship of risk factors (serum cholesterol, blood pressure, weight, smoking) to the subsequent development of cardiovascular diseases
  • Age group: 30 - 62 years
  • Sample size: 5127 (4469 - 69% of the sample actually underwent first examination)
  • Method: Multiple exposure was studied, as well as complex interactions among the exposures using multivariate techniques
  • Follow-up:

- Study population was examined every 2 years for 20 years

- Daily surveillance of hospitalizations at only hospital at Framingham

  • Findings of study:

- Increasing risk of CHD with increasing age & more frequently in males

- Hypertensive have a greater risk of CHD

- Elevated blood cholesterol level is associated with CHD

- Tobacco smoking and habitual use of alcohol are associated with increased risk of CHD

- Increased physical activity is associated with decrease in CHD development

- Increase in body weight is associated predisposes to CHD

- Diabetes mellitus increases risk of CHD

Reference:- Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 3, Page No. 88

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of topical beta blockers, except:
questions.solution:
Beta-Blockers for Intraocular Pressure Control

  • Mechanism of Action: Beta-blockers reduce aqueous humor production, lowering intraocular pressure (IOP). Non-selective beta-blockers (e.g., timolol, levobunolol) are more effective than selective beta-1 blockers (e.g., betaxolol). Betaxolol is preferred in patients with pulmonary diseases like asthma due to fewer side effects.
  • Common Drugs:
    • Timolol (0.25-0.5% drops, twice daily or gel form, once daily)
    • Levobunolol (0.25-0.5% drops, longer half-life)
    • Betaxolol (0.25-0.5% drops, fewer pulmonary side effects, less effective than timolol)
    • Carteolol (1-2% drops, less bradycardia, lower efficacy)
  • Side Effects: Dry eye, bradycardia, bronchial spasms, depression, fatigue.
  • Contraindications: Contraindicated in asthma, chronic bronchitis, atrioventricular blocks, and cardiac failure.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of The Eye, 22nd Edition, page number 157.

questions.text: Frey's syndrome during the parotid surgery occurs due to cross innervation of auriculotemporal nerve with which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Sweating and flushing of a patch of skin near the ear that occurs when someone is eating, due to damage to auriculotemporal nerve(ATN).

Frey's syndrome is a rare complication of surgery or an injury of the salivary (parotid) gland in the cheek. Aberrant Cross innervations between secretomotor parasympathetic fibers (ATN)of Parotid gland & sympathetic fibers supplying sweat gland.

Symptoms include sweating and flushing on the cheek, temple or near the ear, particularly when eating foods with more intense flavors, such as sour, spicy or salty foods.

Treatment consists of supportive care to manage symptoms. Various treatments have been tried, but their effectiveness is limited.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 274.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a family history of cystic fibrosis presents for genetic counseling. Both she & her partner are carriers for cystic fibrosis. What is the risk of this couple having a child with cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder. If both partners are carriers of the cystic fibrosis gene, the risk of having an affected child is 25% with each pregnancy

  • Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene must be mutated for the individual to have the disease.
  • In this scenario:
    • Each parent contributes one allele for the CFTR gene to their offspring.
    • The possible combinations for their child are:
      • 25% chance of inheriting two normal alleles (not a carrier, not affected).
      • 50% chance of inheriting one normal allele and one mutated allele (carrier, like the parents).
      • 25% chance of inheriting two mutated alleles (affected with cystic fibrosis).

Thus, the couple has a 25% risk of having a child with cystic fibrosis.


Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis 2020

questions.text: A woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with a sudden onset of abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is firm and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Placental abruption occurs when the placenta prematurely detaches from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding and uterine tenderness. The condition can cause fetal distress and requires prompt management.

A) Placenta previa:

  • Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is abnormally located in the lower part of the uterus, covering or being close to the cervix.
  • It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding, especially in the second or third trimester, and is not typically associated with uterine tenderness or abdominal pain.
  • Firm uterine tone and tenderness are not characteristic of placenta previa, making this diagnosis less likely in this case.

B) Placental abruption (Correct Answer):

  • Placental abruption is the most likely diagnosis in this case, given the combination of sudden onset of abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and vaginal bleeding.
  • This condition occurs when the placenta prematurely detaches from the uterine wall, either partially or completely, which leads to bleeding, uterine tenderness, and abdominal pain.
  • The uterus is often firm to palpation, and this is a medical emergency that can result in significant maternal and fetal complications, such as fetal distress, preterm birth, or maternal hemorrhage.
  • Placental abruption requires immediate evaluation and management, including stabilization, monitoring, and sometimes early delivery depending on the severity.

C) Uterine rupture:

  • Uterine rupture is a rare but serious complication that can occur in labor, especially in women with previous cesarean sections or uterine scars.
  • It typically presents with severe abdominal pain, but it is more likely to cause hypovolemic shock, loss of fetal heart tones, and cessation of uterine contractions.
  • The patient would typically be in active labor or have risk factors like a previous uterine scar, making uterine rupture less likely in this case, as no clear labor or scar history is given.

D) Preterm labor:

  • Preterm labor is associated with uterine contractions and cervical changes, but it does not usually present with vaginal bleeding or abdominal tenderness as a primary symptom.
  • In preterm labor, contractions are typically regular, and the cervix may be dilating, but the patient usually does not present with a firm or tender uterus as seen in placental abruption.

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 10 Antepartum Haemorrhage, Page no. 156

questions.text: Rajesh and Priya, a married couple, visit a government hospital to inquire about sterilization. They are curious about their eligibility. Rajesh is 26 years old, and Priya is 21 years old. They have two children. The counsellor explains the government guidelines for sterilization, mentioning age limits and other criteria. As the couple discusses further, Priya asks, 'What if we had three children instead of two? Would the age criteria still apply?' The counsellor smiles and says, "In that case, the lower age limit might be relaxed." Based on the situation, what is the correct interpretation of the guidelines for sterilization?
questions.solution:
Following are the guidelines issued by government for sterilization:-

  • The age of the husband should not be less than 25 years nor more than 50 years.
  • The age of the wife should not be less than 20 years not more than 45 years.
  • The motivated couple must have 2 living children at the time of operation.
  • If the couple has 3 or more living children the lower limit of age of the husband and wife may be relaxed.
  • It is sufficient if the acceptor declares having obtained consent of his/her spouse to undergo sterilization procedure without any outside pressure.

Reference:- Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 8, Page No. 583

questions.text: Which of the following rubella genotypes is most commonly found worldwide, including in India?
questions.solution:
• A) Genotype 1E: This is a circulating genotype but is not the most predominant globally.
  • B) Genotype 1G: Another circulating genotype but not as widespread as Genotype 2B.
  • C) Genotype 1J: While found in some regions, it is less common than Genotype 2B.
  • D) Genotype 2B: This is the most predominant rubella genotype worldwide and is also the most common in India, as described in epidemiology data.

Key Takeaway:

Genotype 2B is the most common rubella genotype globally and is the predominant strain in India.

Reference:

Epidemiology section, describing the global and Indian distribution of rubella genotypes.

Reference:

Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 56 PP 563.

questions.text: A child with Hirschsprung's disease is at risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
1. Enterocolitis is a life-threatening complication of Hirschsprung's disease, characterized by inflammation of the colon and small intestine.
  2. Intestinal obstruction can occur due to the functional obstruction caused by the absence of ganglion cells.
  3. Malnutrition can result from intestinal obstruction, enterocolitis, or chronic diarrhea.

Key Takeaways:

  • Also called congenital aganglionic megacolon
  • Absence of enteric ganglia causes a loss of intrinsic excitatory and inhibitory innervation; net effect is spastic contraction of aganglionic segment, including internal anal sphincter, with impaired peristalsis and defecation
  • Bowel proximal to the aganglionic segment undergoes muscular hypertrophy and dilation
  • Abnormal extrinsic innervation (enlarged cholinergic nerves) in aganglionic rectum + / - more proximal aganglionic left colon may contribute to spasticity
  • Most common presentation: failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth
  • Other findings may include abdominal distension, bilious emesis, explosive defecation in response to manual anal dilatation, bowel perforation and enterocolitis
  • Complications:proximal innervated colon may become massively distended (15 cm in diameter) with muscular wall hypertrophy and rupture / perforation, usually near cecum or appendix; also acute intestinal obstruction, enterocolitis with fluid and electrolyte imbalance

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 756.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a history of chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He has a past history of alcohol abuse and has been experiencing fatigue and weakness. On physical examination, he has clubbing of the fingers and a lung auscultation revealing crackles in the right lower lobe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Tuberculosis may present similarly, but alcohol history and symptoms of weight loss and hemoptysis point more towards lung cancer.
  • Option B: The most likely diagnosis is lung cancer, especially in a patient with a smoking history, the patient's age, weight loss, hemoptysis, and clubbing.
  • Option C: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease would not typically present with hemoptysis and weight loss in this manner.
  • Option D: Pneumonia typically presents acutely and with more localized symptoms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Clubbing, weight loss, and hemoptysis in an adult with alcohol use history are suggestive of lung cancer.
REFERENCE: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 78, page 798

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of recurrent preeclampsia is found to have high uterine artery resistance during her first-trimester ultrasound. Which molecule involved in trophoblast invasion is most likely dysregulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
1. A) Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)
  • VEGF promotes angiogenesis and vascular remodeling. While it plays a role in pregnancy, dysregulation of VEGF itself is less directly associated with preeclampsia compared to its inhibitors.
  1. B) Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β)
  • TGF-β influences various cellular processes, including differentiation and invasion. However, it is not a primary molecule implicated in the pathophysiology of preeclampsia.
  1. C) Placental growth factor (PlGF)
  • PlGF is crucial for placental angiogenesis. Decreased levels are seen in preeclampsia, but its dysregulation is secondary to an increase in anti-angiogenic factors such as sFlt-1.
  1. D) Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1)
  • Correct Answer. sFlt-1 is an anti-angiogenic protein that binds to VEGF and PlGF, reducing their bioavailability. Elevated levels of sFlt-1 are strongly associated with preeclampsia and impair trophoblast invasion and placental perfusion.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 40 Preeclampsia Syndrome, Page no. 1794

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in (FMT)
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism.

In masochism, the person obtains sexual gratification by suffering pain. Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia (autoerotic death). It is more common in males.

Other options -

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. A fetish is an abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males. It is harmless, but rarely it may drive the person to obtain his fetish object through violence or criminal act.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among male, who gets sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc. of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 335

questions.text: A 2 year male child presented with Developmental delay, Hepatosplenomegaly, Coarse Facials Features, Mental Retardation. No corneal Clouding. Enzyme deficiency in this suspected case of Mucopolysaccharidoses is
questions.solution:
Case history of Mucopolysacchariodoses presented in symptomatic Male Child (suggestive of X linked), No corneal clouding ( differentiating feature of Hunter’s Syndrome) . Most other MPS are autosomal recessive (e.g., MPS I, III, IV, VI, VII). Both males and females are equally affected

Enzyme deficiency seen in Hunter’s Syndrome is Iduronate Sulfatase.

  • MPS I (Hurler/Scheie): α-L-iduronidase deficiency.
  • MPS III (Sanfilippo): Deficiency in one of four enzymes involved in heparan sulfate degradation.
  • MPS IV (Morquio): Deficiency of galactosamine-6-sulfatase or β-galactosidase.
  • MPS VI (Maroteaux-Lamy): Arylsulfatase B deficiency.
  • Sly Syndrome - B Glucuronidase Deficiency


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 50 Page 611

questions.text: Match the following waste disposal method with the type of waste it is 'contraindicated' for?
questions.solution:
• Incineration: - Incineration is a high temperature dry oxidation process, that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic incombustible matter. Wastes type not to be incinerated are:
  • Pressurized gas containers.
  • Large amount of reactive chemical wastes.
  • Silver salts and photographic or radiographic wastes.
  • Halogenated plastics such as PVC.
  • Waste with high mercury or cadmium content such as broken thermometers, used batteries and lead-linen wooden panels.
  • Sealed ampoules or ampoules containing heavy metals.
  • Wet thermal treatment: - Wet thermal treatment or steam disinfection is based on exposure of shredded infectious wastes to high temperature, high pressure steam, and is similar to the autoclave sterilization process. The process is inappropriate for the treatment of anatomical waste and animal carcasses and will not efficiently treat chemical and pharmaceutical waste.
  • Screw feed technology: - It is the basis of a non-burn, dry thermal disinfection process in which waste is shredded and heated in a rotating auger. The waste is reduced by 80% in volume and by 30-35% in weight. This process is suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps, but it should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic or radioactive waste.
  • Inertization: - It involves mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal, in order to minimize the risk of toxic substances contained in the wastes. Typical proportion of the mixture is 65% pharmaceutical waste, 15% lime, 15% cement and 5% water. This method is not applicable for infectious waste.

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no. 916,917,918

questions.text: A 45 year old woman recently diagnosed with a urinary tract infection started therapy with a trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination. Both trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole are bacteriostatic drugs when given alone. However, a bactericidal effect is obtained when the two drugs are given in combination. Which of the following terms best defines this drug interaction?
questions.solution:
• A drug interaction is defined as synergistic when the response elicited by combined drugs is greater than the combined responses of the individual drugs.
  • In other words, the response elicited by the drug combination is more than simply additive.
  • In the present case, the effects of the individual drugs are bacteriostatic, whereas the effect of the combined drugs is more than an additive bacteriostatic effect (by definition, a bactericidal effect is greater than a bacteriostatic effect).
  • The interaction is therefore defined as synergism.
  • SYNERGISM
  • (Greek: Syn—together; ergon—work)
  • When the action of one drug is facilitated or increased by the other, they are said to be synergistic.
  • In a synergistic pair, both the drugs can have action in the same direction or given alone one may be inactive but still enhance the action of the other when given together.
  • Synergism can be:
  • Additive
  • The effect of the two drugs is in the same direction and simply adds up:
  • Effect of drugs A + B = effect of drug A + effect of drug B
  • Side effects of the components of an additive pair may be different—do not add up.
  • Thus, the combination is better tolerated than higher dose of one component.
  • Supraadditive (potentiation)
  • The effect of combination is greater than the individual effects of the components:
  • Effect of drug A + B > effect of drug A + effect of drug B
  • This is always the case when one component given alone produces no effect, but enhances the effect of the other (potentiation).


Option A: Additive effects occurs when the response elicited by combined drugs is equal to the combined responses of the individual drugs.

Option C & D: These terms refer to drug effects that increase over time, when the drug is chronically given.

  • Key takeaway
  • A drug interaction is defined as synergistic when the response elicited by combined drugs is greater than the combined responses of the individual drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 66-67

questions.text: Misfolded Tau protein in Alzheimer's disease forms which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Misfolded Tau protein in Alzheimer's disease becomes hyperphosphorylated and aggregates inside neurons. These aggregates form neurofibrillary tangles, a hallmark of Alzheimer's pathology. The accumulation of these tangles disrupts microtubule stability and impairs intracellular transport, leading to neuronal dysfunction and death

Option A) Amyloid plaques :These are extracellular deposits of Amyloid-beta (Aβ), not Tau protein. Amyloid plaques are another key feature of Alzheimer's disease but are unrelated to Tau. The AB that is deposited in the brain in AD is derived by Enzyme cleavages from the larger amyloid precursor protein, a single transmembrane protein expressed on the cell surface in the brain and other tissues.

Option B) Lewy bodies :Lewy bodies consist of misfolded alpha-synuclein and are characteristic of Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, not Alzheimer's.

Option D) Prion aggregates: Prion aggregates are associated with prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and are not a feature of Alzheimer's disease. Prion Protein is the causative agent of transmissible spongioform encephalopathy like CJD. No primary structure difference or alternate posttranslational modification have been found between the normal and infectious forms of the protein. The key to becoming infectious apparently lies in change in the three dimensional conformation of PrPc.

Protein folding is a complex process - may result in improperly folded molecule. Depostit of Misfolded proteins are associated with number of diseases like Amyloid Diseases / Prion Disease.


Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 7 Page 96-97

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, tachycardia, oliguria, and metabolic acidosis. Abdominal radiographs reveal pneumobilia and an obstructing mass consistent with a high suspicion of gallstone ileus. During exploratory laparotomy, what is the optimal surgical approach to address the bowel obstruction while minimizing perioperative morbidity in this hemodynamically unstable, elderly patient?''
questions.solution:
Option D: At laparotomy, the stone should be milked proximally away from the site of impaction. It may be possible to crush the stone within the bowel lumen; if not, the intestine is opened at this point and the gallstone is removed. If the gallstone is faceted, a careful check for other enteric stones should be made. The region of the gallbladder should not be explored.

Option A: Pushing the stone distally into the bowel may result in obstruction at another, potentially less accessible site, particularly if the bowel becomes progressively narrower (e.g., at the ileocecal valve).

Option B: Resection is unnecessary because it might lead to the need for anastomosis in an unstable patient who is also old. Hence not advisable.

Option C: Cholecystectomy in an acute setting is not to be done. Hence this option is incorrect.

Key Take Away Point:

A cholecystoenteric fistula should not be resected unless the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.


References:Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 1377 / 1248

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which bacteria ascend from the bladder to the kidneys to cause pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
A) Hematogenous spread: Hematogenous spread refers to the spread of bacteria through the bloodstream. While this can occur in certain cases of pyelonephritis, it is not the primary mechanism.

B) Lymphatic spread: Lymphatic spread refers to the spread of bacteria through the lymphatic system. This is not a common mechanism of pyelonephritis.

C) Ascending infection via the ureters: Ascending infection via the ureters is the primary mechanism by which bacteria ascend from the bladder to the kidneys to cause pyelonephritis. Bacteria can ascend through the ureters due to various factors, such as vesicoureteral reflux or urinary tract obstruction.

D) Direct extension from the bladder: Direct extension from the bladder is not a common mechanism of pyelonephritis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ascending infection via the ureters is the primary mechanism by which bacteria ascend from the bladder to the kidneys to cause pyelonephritis.
  • Vesicoureteral reflux and urinary tract obstruction can facilitate ascending infection by allowing bacteria to ascend through the ureters.

    • REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 927.
