questions.text: How is Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) primarily transmitted?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is primarily transmitted through intimate oral contact, such as kissing or sharing utensils. It is commonly known as the "kissing disease" due to its mode of transmission.

1.Overview:

  • Virus Type: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a member of the Herpesviridae family.
  • Also Known As: Human Herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4).

2.Transmission:

  • Primary Route: Spread primarily through saliva (e.g., kissing), hence it is sometimes referred to as the 'kissing disease.'
  • Other Routes: Can also be transmitted through blood, organ transplantation, and from mother to child during childbirth.

3.Clinical Manifestations:

  • Infectious Mononucleosis: Characterized by fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue. It is the most common manifestation.
  • Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: EBV has been associated with chronic fatigue syndrome, although this link is still being studied.
  • Associated Cancers: EBV is linked to several cancers, including Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

4.Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Evaluation: Based on symptoms and physical examination.
  • Serology: Detection of specific antibodies (e.g., heterophile antibodies) in the blood.
  • PCR Testing: Detects EBV DNA in blood or tissues for more precise diagnosis.

5.Treatment:

  • Infectious Mononucleosis: Typically managed with supportive care, including rest, hydration, and pain relief. Antiviral medications are not usually required.
  • Complications: Treatment for complications, such as associated cancers, depends on the specific condition.

6.Prevention:

  • Avoiding Close Contact: Reducing contact with saliva from infected individuals.
  • No Vaccine: There is currently no vaccine available for EBV.

Reference:Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Epstein-Barr Virus and Infectious Mononucleosis. Retrieved from CDC Epstein-Barr Virus

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, and a persistent dry cough for the last two weeks. His past medical history includes smoking and recent exposure to a coworker with similar symptoms. Chest X-ray shows a consolidation in the right lower lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Community-acquired pneumonia is the most likely diagnosis given the fever, cough, and consolidation on chest X-ray, particularly in a smoker with exposure to a colleague with similar symptoms.
  • Option B: Tuberculosis typically presents with a chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, not a sudden onset like this.
  • Option C: Lung cancer generally does not present with fever and consolidation on X-ray.
  • Option D: Sarcoidosis can cause lung involvement, but it would not present with a localized consolidation on chest X-ray.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Community-acquired pneumonia presents with fever, cough, and consolidation on chest X-ray, especially in smokers.
REFERENCE: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 126, page 1011

choices.text: To promote cell growth and division
To remove damaged or unnecessary cells
To increase the number of cells in tissues
To enhance inflammation in response to injury

questions.text: What is the primary function of apoptosis in multicellular organisms?
questions.solution:
A) To promote cell growth and division

While cell growth and division are essential processes in development and tissue maintenance, they are not functions of apoptosis.

  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death mechanism that ensures cells that are damaged, aged, or no longer needed are eliminated.

B) To remove damaged or unnecessary cells

Apoptosis is a controlled process that eliminates cells that are no longer needed or are potentially harmful to the organism (such as cells with DNA damage). This process is crucial for maintaining tissue homeostasis and preventing diseases such as cancer.

C) To increase the number of cells in tissues

Apoptosis does not increase the number of cells; in fact, it leads to a decrease in cell number. The balance between cell proliferation (growth) and apoptosis is critical for maintaining healthy tissues.

D) To enhance inflammation in response to injury

While inflammation is an important response to injury, apoptosis itself is not a mechanism that enhances inflammation.

  • Instead, apoptosis can help resolve inflammation by removing immune cells after their job is done, thus preventing excessive inflammation and tissue damage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Apoptosis is a vital process for maintaining cellular health by removing damaged or unnecessary cells.
  • It plays a crucial role in development, tissue homeostasis, and preventing diseases such as cancer.
  • Understanding apoptosis helps in comprehending various biological processes, including how the body responds to injury and maintains balance in cellpopulations.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 42.

questions.text: Health communication is very important aspect from public health point of view because of the various functions it has. All of the following are functions of health communication except?
questions.solution:
• Health communication has to cater to the following needs: -
  • Information: - The primary function of Health Communication is to provide scientific knowledge or information to provide about health problems and how to maintain and promote health.
  • Education: - Education of the general public as an integral part of the prevention-oriented approach to health and disease problems and the basis of all education is communication.
  • Motivation: - It is a power that drives a person from within to act. One of the goals of Health Communication is to motivate individuals to translate health information into personal behaviour and lifestyle for their own health.
  • Persuasion: - The sole purpose of communication is to influence. Persuasion is a conscious attempt by one individual to change on influence the general beliefs, understanding, values and behaviour of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way.
  • Counselling: - Counselling is a process that can help people understand better and deal with their problems and communicate better with those with whom they are emotionally involved.
  • Raising morale: - Morale is the capacity of a group of people to pull together persistently or consistently. Communication vertical and horizontal internal and external is the first step in any attempt to raise morale of the health team or a group of people.
  • Health development: - Communication can play a powerful role in health development by helping to defuse knowledge in respect of the goals of development and preparing the people for the roles expected of them.
  • Health organisation: - Communication is the life and blood of an organisation. There are two major directions in which communications within an organisation flow, these are vertical and horizontal communications.

Reference:Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.984,985.

questions.text: Germ Cells do not senesce because of
questions.solution:
Germ Cell, Stem cell and Cancer cells, telomeres do not shorten and the cells do not senesce. This is a result of the ribonucleoprotein telomerase which maintain telomeric length in these cells.

Eukaryotic cells during Replication process, removal of the RNA primer from the extreme 5' end of the lagging strand, there is no way to fill the remaining gap with DNA. Most normal human somatic cells, telomeres shorten with each successive cell division. Once telomere shorten beyond some cirtical length the cell is no longer to divide and is said to be senescent.

Telomerase contain a protein that acts as a reverse transcriptase and short piece of RNA tat acts as a template.

Option A) Presence of Ribonucleoprotein Endonuclease: This refers to enzymes involved in RNA processing and is unrelated to telomere maintenance.

Option B) Absence of Telomerase: The absence of telomerase leads to telomere shortening and senescence, which does not occur in germ cells.

Option D) Presence of Polymerase A: DNA polymerase α is involved in DNA replication but does not maintain telomeres.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 35 Page 602

questions.text: True about measles is all except:
questions.solution:
MEASLES (RUBEOLA):

  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days
  • Causative agent: RNA paramyxovirus (so for only one serotype known)
  • Source of Infection: cases (carriers are not known to occur)
  • Period of Communicability: 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash (Rash: Retro-auricular origin)
  • Measles has no second attacks (lifelong immunity seen)
  • Secondary attack rate of Measles: 80%
  • Measles shows a cyclical trend: Increase every 2-3 years
  • Blood cell type predominantly infected in Measles: Monocyte
  • Pathognomic clinical feature of Measles: Koplik spots (on buccal mucosa opposite upper 2nd molar)
  • Pathognomic microscopic feature of Measles: Warthin Finkledy cells (multinucleated giant cells)
  • MC complication of measles in young children: Otitis media
  • SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis) is a rare complication of measles: 7 per million cases of Measles (7-10 years after initial infection)
  • Epidemic of measles occur: If proportion of susceptible children is >40%
  • If Measles is introduced in a virgin community: it infects >90% children
  • Eradication of Measles: Requires a vaccination coverage >96%
  • Baby measles (Exanthem subitum-roseola infantum): Sixth disease (three-day fever) caused by HHV6
  • German Measles: Rubella
  • Measles is prevented by:
    • Active immunization by measles vaccine
    • Passive immunization by measles immunoglobulin

Reference:- Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 5, Page No. 164

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding and a Pap smear showing atypical glandular cells. What is the next most appropriate management step?
questions.solution:
Atypical glandular cells on Pap smear suggest possible endometrial or cervical cancer. Endocervical curettage is necessary to obtain a tissue sample for further evaluation and rule out malignancy.

In a 50-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding and a Pap smear showing atypical glandular cells (AGC), the next most appropriate management step is endocervical curettage (ECC). AGC on a Pap smear can be indicative of potential endometrial or cervical pathology, including endometrial cancer, cervical adenocarcinoma, or precancerous lesions.

  • Endocervical curettage (ECC) helps to collect tissue from the endocervix to identify possible malignant or premalignant changes. This procedure is especially important because glandular cell abnormalities often involve the endocervical canal, where visual inspection alone may not suffice to detect pathology.
  • Repeat Pap smear (Option A) is not the appropriate next step because AGC warrants further investigation to rule out malignancy, not just observation.
  • Colposcopy (Option B) is typically used for evaluating abnormal squamous cells and is not as effective in evaluating glandular abnormalities.
  • HPV testing (Option D) is useful in cases of squamous abnormalities but does not provide enough diagnostic value when glandular abnormalities like AGC are present.

Reference: American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP). Management of women with abnormal cervical cancer screening tests. ASCCP 2019 guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following features is least likely to be associated with early-stage papilloedema?
questions.solution:
Papilloedema:

Definition:

Papilloedema is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This non-inflammatory condition arises as the optic nerve sheath, continuous with brain meninges, transmits raised ICP to the optic disc.

Pathogenesis:

  1. Mechanism:
    • Blockage of axoplasmic transport in optic nerve fibers.
    • Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure causes axoplasmic stasis and optic disc swelling.
    • Secondary vascular changes occur on the disc surface.
  2. Key Factor:
    • Relief is possible with procedures like optic nerve sheath fenestration.

Pathology:

  • Features:
    • Passive edema at the optic nerve head.
    • Engorged, tortuous vessels; swollen axons with disrupted mitochondria.
    • Retinal and macular involvement (e.g., macular star, cotton-wool spots).
    • Chronic cases lead to secondary optic atrophy.

Aetiology:

  1. Primary Cause:
    • Increased ICP due to conditions like brain tumors, hydrocephalus, pseudotumor cerebri, or subarachnoid hemorrhage
  2. Other Causes:
    • Malignant hypertension.
    • Venous thrombosis, aneurysms, or abscesses.

Clinical Features:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Early stages: transient blurred vision, episodic blackouts, headache, nausea, vomiting.
    • Advanced stages: progressive vision loss, enlarged blind spots, optic atrophy.
  2. Signs:
    • Early: blurred optic disc margins, hyperemia, reduced venous pulsations.
    • Progressive: disc swelling, hemorrhages, exudates, macular star, and tortuous veins.
    • Late: optic atrophy and irreversible vision loss.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on ophthalmoscopic findings, ICP measurement, and neuroimaging to exclude other causes.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of The Eye, 22nd Edition, page number 350.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common source of spread of infection for Liver Abscess in the West?
questions.solution:
Biliary tract pathology is the most common source (35%), followed by portal spread from the gastrointestinal tract, including diverticulitis and appendicitis (20%). Other unusual aetiologies include contiguous spread from subphrenic or intra-abdominal collections, bacteremia secondary to trauma or infected cysts, and necrotic tumors following chemotherapy.

The cause is not identified in 10% of cases and a number of liver abscesses become recurrent (12-38% depending on whether the responsible organism is identified and whether the patient has diabetes).

Option A: It is the second most common cause
Option B: It is the main cause of liver abscesses in the west
Option C: Alcohol is one of the causes of liver abscess but not common

Option D: Intrahepatic stone/ cholangitis are mc cause in Asia.

Key Takeaway Point:

In Asia, intrahepatic stones and cholangitis (recurrent pyogenic cholangitis [RPC];) are common causes, whereas in the West, malignant obstruction has become a more predominant cause.

Reference:
Bailey and Love 28th Ed Page - 1209
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Ed - Page - 1453

choices.text: They promote healing of lung tissue.

questions.text: What role do neutrophils play in the pathogenesis of acute lung injury?
questions.solution:
A) They promote healing of lung tissue: Neutrophils are primarily involved in the inflammatory response rather than healing.

B) They release pro-inflammatory mediators: This is correct. Neutrophils release cytokines and other mediators that contribute to inflammation and tissue damage in ALI.

C) They decrease vascular permeability: Neutrophils actually increase permeability through their inflammatory actions.

D) They enhance surfactant production: Neutrophils do not play a direct role in surfactant production.

Key Takeaway:

Neutrophils are key players in the inflammatory response during ALI, releasing mediators that exacerbate lung injury.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 676.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of acute pericarditis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - The most common cause of acute pericarditis is viral infection, especially from viruses like coxsackievirus and echovirus.

OPTION B - While bacterial infections (e.g., tuberculosis) can cause pericarditis, they are less common than viral causes.

OPTION C - Fungal infections are rare causes of pericarditis and are generally seen in immunocompromised individuals.

OPTION D - Radiation therapy can lead to pericardial fibrosis, but it is a less common cause of acute pericarditis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Acute pericarditis is most commonly caused by viral infections. Treatment often focuses on managing the inflammation and the underlying cause.

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 270 PAGE 2019

questions.text: 55-year-old man presents for a routine colonoscopy. A 1.5 cm polyp is found in the sigmoid colon and is described as having a soft, velvety appearance. Histological examination reveals small pdenculated polyps composed of rounded/tubular glands. What is the most likely type of adenoma found in this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Tubular adenoma: This is the most common type of adenoma found in the colon, often described as having a smooth surface. The description of the polyp in this case fits this type.
  2. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type has both tubular and villous components and tends to have a higher risk of malignancy than purely tubular adenomas.
  3. Villous adenoma: Typically larger and has a higher risk of cancer. This polyp’s description does not fit this type.
  4. Serrated adenoma: Characterized by a serrated architecture. The histological findings do not suggest this type.

Key Takeaway:

Tubular adenomas are common and have low malignant potential compared to other types.

Recognizing the morphology of adenomas is essential for appropriate management.

Sigmoid colon, tubular adenoma.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 811.

choices.text: Use of GnRH antagonists in ovulation induction

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?
questions.solution:
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is one of the most significant risk factors for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS). Women with PCOS typically have an increased number of ovarian follicles, which makes them more sensitive to stimulation during ovulation induction, especially in assisted reproductive technologies (ART) like in vitro fertilization (IVF). This heightened sensitivity can lead to excessive ovarian response and the development of OHSS, a condition where the ovaries become swollen and painful due to fluid accumulation.

Here's why the other options are not significant risk factors:

  • A) Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is associated with lower ovarian reserve and fewer oocytes, it is not directly linked to an increased risk of OHSS compared to conditions like PCOS.
  • B) Low AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone): Low AMH levels typically indicate a reduced ovarian reserve and a lower number of follicles, which would actually reduce the risk of OHSS, rather than increase it.
  • D) Use of GnRH antagonists in ovulation induction: GnRH antagonists are often used in ART to prevent premature ovulation, thus reducing the risk of OHSS, not increasing it. In contrast, the use of GnRH agonists or high doses of gonadotropins is more commonly associated with an increased risk.

Reference: American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM). "Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)."

questions.text: Which is the longest part of optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Parts of the Optic Nerve

The optic nerve is approximately 47-50 mm in length and consists of 4 parts:

  1. Intraocular Part (1 mm): Starts at the optic disc, passes through the choroid and sclera (forming the lamina cribrosa), and connects to the intraorbital part.
  2. Intraorbital Part (30 mm): Extends from the back of the eyeball to the optic foramina. It is slightly curved to accommodate eye movements and is surrounded by the annulus of Zinn, where it is close to the origin of the rectus muscles.
  3. Intracanalicular Part (6-9 mm): Located near the ophthalmic artery and sphenoid and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Its proximity to the sinuses can lead to retrobulbar neuritis following sinus infections.
  4. Intracranial Part (10 mm): Lies above the cavernous sinus and converges with the other optic nerve to form the optic chiasma.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, AK Khurana, 6th Edition, page number 310-311

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
A DEXA scan is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis by measuring bone mineral density (BMD) and calculating T-scores.

Option wise analysis:

A) Serum calcium levels
Explanation:
Serum calcium levels are not a reliable diagnostic tool for osteoporosis. Although calcium is important for bone health, its serum concentration may not reflect bone density or the presence of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by low bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, which cannot be assessed by serum calcium alone.

B) Bone biopsy
Explanation:
A bone biopsy is a more invasive procedure and is generally not used in the diagnosis of osteoporosis. It may be helpful in diagnosing other bone disorders or conditions that mimic osteoporosis, but it is not the standard method for diagnosing osteoporosis.

C) Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
Explanation:
The DEXA scan is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis. It measures bone mineral density (BMD), and a T-score of -2.5 or lower indicates osteoporosis. DEXA is non-invasive, quick, and has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting low bone density and assessing fracture risk.

D) X-ray of the spine
Explanation:
While X-rays can reveal fractures and significant bone loss, they are not sensitive enough for early diagnosis of osteoporosis. X-rays typically show changes only after significant bone loss has occurred, so they are not useful for detecting osteoporosis in its early stages.

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 21 Menopausal transition, Page no. 479-480

choices.text: Direct and indirect contact with infected nasal and throat secretions

questions.text: How is Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) primarily transmitted?
questions.solution:
• A) Airborne transmission through respiratory droplets: While respiratory droplets can play a role in transmission, the primary mode of transmission for HFMD is direct and indirect contact with infected secretions.
  • B) Direct and indirect contact with infected nasal and throat secretions: This is the most common method of transmission. It includes contact with saliva, nasal mucus, and fluid from blisters or scabs, as well as feces.
  • C) Only through fecal-oral transmission: Fecal-oral transmission is one of the routes but not the sole method of transmission for HFMD.
  • D) Through insect bites: Insect bites are not involved in the transmission of HFMD, which is a viral infection caused by enteroviruses.

Key Takeaway:

  • HFMD is mainly spread through direct or indirect contact with infected nasal, throat secretions, blister fluid, and feces.

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 56 PP 564.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless lump in the right breast. On examination, the lump is firm, mobile, and well-defined. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
A fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor, typically presenting as a firm, mobile, and painless lump. It is most commonly found in women under 30 years of age.

Explanation:

A) Fibroadenoma (Correct Answer):

  • Fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. It is the most common benign breast tumor, typically found in young women, particularly those under 30 years of age.
  • These lumps are usually painless, firm, mobile, and well-defined, which matches the clinical description in the question.
  • Fibroadenomas are composed of glandular and stromal tissue and can vary in size. They are typically round or oval in shape and are freely movable within the breast tissue, which makes them feel mobile on examination.
  • Ultrasound or mammography is often used for further evaluation, and in many cases, biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

B) Breast cancer:

  • Breast cancer often presents with a firm, non-mobile lump that may be fixed to surrounding tissues. It is typically more irregular in shape, and although it can be painless, it is more likely to be associated with other symptoms such as skin changes (e.g., dimpling), nipple discharge, or axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Breast cancer can occur in women of all ages, but the presentation of a firm, mobile, well-defined, painless lump is less characteristic of malignant tumors, especially in younger women.

C) Cystosarcoma phyllodes:

  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes is a rare fibroepithelial tumor that can present with a rapidly growing, painless, and firm lump, which can also be mobile.
  • However, phyllodes tumors are typically larger than fibroadenomas and can show rapid growth. They can also have a more irregular shape compared to fibroadenomas.
  • While benign forms exist, malignant phyllodes tumors are aggressive and often associated with larger tumors and other concerning features.

D) Mastitis:

  • Mastitis is an infection of the breast, usually occurring in lactating women (though it can occur in non-lactating women as well).
  • It typically presents with pain, redness, warmth, and swelling in the breast, often with fever and flu-like symptoms. A painless lump is not characteristic of mastitis, which tends to be associated with inflammation and infection.
  • Mastitis is less likely in a 30-year-old woman with a well-defined, painless lump, especially if she is not breastfeeding.

Reference: American Cancer Society Breast Cancer: Early Detection and Diagnosis 2020

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine should not be frozen?
questions.solution:
• OPV, BCG and Measles are stable from freezing. Rest all other vaccines are sensitive to freezing and must not be frozen.

Reference: IAP guidebook on immunization, 3rd ed., pg. 52

questions.text: A dairy farmer presents with intermittent fever, night sweats, arthralgia, and fatigue. He reports handling livestock and consuming unpasteurized milk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is caused by Brucella species, transmitted through contact with infected animals or their products like unpasteurized milk. It manifests as undulant fever (intermittent fever), arthralgia, and fatigue. Commonly associated with farmers, veterinarians, and dairy workers. Control involves pasteurization of milk and vaccination of cattle.

Diagnosis: ELISA, PCR, culture

Reference:- Park's Textbook Of Preventive And Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter: 5, Page No. 337

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation is admitted for preterm labor. After initial management with fluids and corticosteroids, nifedipine is administered. Which of the following is a potential side effect of nifedipine in this setting?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to manage preterm labor by inhibiting uterine contractions. A common side effect of nifedipine is maternal hypotension, as it causes vasodilation and decreases peripheral vascular resistance. This can lead to a drop in blood pressure, particularly when administered in high doses. Other side effects may include dizziness and flushing, but hypotension is the most clinically significant in this context.

Option wise Explanation:

  • A) Hyperkalemia: Not typically associated with nifedipine. Hyperkalemia may occur with certain medications (e.g., potassium-sparing diuretics), but not with nifedipine.
  • B) Maternal hypotension: Correct answer. Nifedipine can cause maternal hypotension due to its vasodilatory effect, leading to decreased blood pressure.
  • C) Hyperglycemia: This is more commonly seen with corticosteroid use (e.g., in preterm labor) rather than with nifedipine.
  • D) Tachycardia: Nifedipine can cause reflex tachycardia, but hypotension is a more prominent side effect and a more immediate concern in preterm labor management.

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 8, Preterm Birth, Page no. 139

questions.text: Phosphofructokinase 1 is inhibited by all except
questions.solution:
Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a crucial enzyme in the regulation of glycolysis. It controls the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, which is a key regulatory step in the glycolytic pathway. PFK-1 activity is tightly regulated by various metabolites and hormones to ensure that energy production is balanced with the cell's needs.

Option A) ATP is a major product of glycolysis and an indicator of the cell's energy status. When ATP levels are high, there is less need for energy production, so ATP inhibits PFK-1 to prevent further breakdown of glucose.

Option B) Glucagon is a hormone released during low blood sugar levels. It signals the liver to produce glucose via gluconeogenesis and inhibits glycolysis.

Glucagon indirectly inhibits PFK-1 by decreasing the levels of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which is an activator of PFK-1. Thus, glucagon has an indirect inhibitory effect on PFK-1.

Option C) Citrate is an intermediate of the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When cellular energy levels are high (indicating abundant ATP), citrate accumulates and inhibits PFK-1, signaling to decrease rate of glycolysis.

Option D) Aspartate is an amino acid that does not directly regulate PFK-1 activity. In contrast to ATP, citrate, and glucagon, aspartate does not inhibit PFK-1.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 19 Page 184

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of primary infertility for 3 years. His semen analysis shows a low sperm count, poor motility, and normal morphology. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Varicocele (A): The most common cause of male infertility, leading to impaired spermatogenesis due to heat stress and venous congestion.
  • Klinefelter syndrome (B): A chromosomal abnormality (47,XXY) that causes low sperm count and small testes but typically has abnormal morphology.
  • Obstructive azoospermia (C): Caused by blockages in the male reproductive tract, leading to no sperm in the ejaculate.
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (D): Results in low testosterone levels but would show low FSH/LH levels, not a semen analysis finding.

Reference: The World Health Organization (WHO) laboratory manual for the examination and processing of human semen (5th edition)
