Pain abdomen must be present for >3months with onset >6months
Associated with change in frequency and form of stool

questions.text: True regarding ROME IV criteria for IBS except?
questions.solution:
OPTION A- Abdominal discomfort is replaced by abdominal pain.

OPTION B&C- Both are correct options

OPTION D- Option A is false, so it is incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAY- In a young female with pain abdomen with no fever, weight loss, bleed in stool and chronic diarrhoea exacerbated with stress IBS must be suspected.

REFERENCE- HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 327 PAGE2490

questions.text: All the following constitute primary active transport except
questions.solution:
Active transport is vectorial movement of a solute across a membrane against a concentration gradient, and thus requires energy (frequently derived from the hydrolysis of ATP); a specific transporter (pump) is involved.

Primary Active Transport: Involves the direct use of energy (usually from ATP hydrolysis) to move ions or molecules against their concentration gradient.

Examples include:

  • Sodium-potassium pump (Na-/K+-ATPase): Actively pumps Na+ out and K+ into the cell using ATP.
  • Calcium pump (Ca2++-ATPase): Actively pumps Ca2+ out of the cell or into organelles like the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Potassium-hydrogen pump (H+/K+ATPase): Pumps H+ out and K+ into cells (e.g., gastric parietal cells), using ATP.

Secondary Active Transport:

  • Relies on the electrochemical gradient established by primary active transport.
  • Na-Glucose Transporter (SGLT) is an example of secondary active transport.
  • The Na+-glucose transporter does not use ATP directly. Instead, it depends on the sodium gradient created by the ATP-consuming Na+/K+ pump. This makes it a secondary active transporter.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 40

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. She has a history of mild anemia during her childhood and is pregnant at 12 weeks' gestation. Her iron profile shows the following:
- Serum iron: 110 µg/dL (Normal: 50-170 µg/dL)
- Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC): 330 µg/dL (Normal: 240-450 µg/dL)
- Transferrin saturation: 33% (Normal: 20-50%)
- Ferritin: 80 ng/mL (Normal: 15-150 ng/mL)
On Hb electrophoresis, HbA2 level was found to be 3.8%.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option-wise explanation:

  • A) Iron deficiency anemia: This would typically show low serum iron, high TIBC, low ferritin, and low transferrin saturation. However, the patient’s iron profile is normal, so iron deficiency anemia is unlikely.
  • B) Thalassemia minor: This is the most likely diagnosis. The normal iron profile combined with an elevated HbA2 level suggests thalassemia minor, which is a genetic disorder involving reduced production of one of the hemoglobin chains. Patients often have mild anemia with normal iron studies and may not show symptoms other than fatigue and pallor.
  • C) Anemia of chronic disease: This usually presents with normal or low serum iron, low TIBC, and normal or increased ferritin. The patient's iron studies do not show characteristics of anemia of chronic disease, making it unlikely.
  • D) Vitamin B12 deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency typically presents with macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms. The patient's iron profile and lack of macrocytosis make this diagnosis unlikely.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 59 Hematological disorders, Page no. 2751

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple asymptomatic scaly patches varying in color from white to tan to brown to pink. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount, a spaghetti and meatball appearance was seen. Which of the following is the causative organism for this disease?
questions.solution:
The spaghetti and meatball appearance observed on KOH wet mount is characteristic of Malassezia furfur, a superficial fungal infection. The patient exhibits typical symptoms such as scaly patches of various colors (white, tan, brown, pink), which are indicative of pityriasis versicolor, a skin condition caused by Malassezia furfur.

  • Tinea corporis (Option A) is caused by dermatophytes, not Malassezia.
  • Sporotrichosis (Option C) and Blastomycosis (Option D) are caused by different fungi that do not produce the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance.

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 58 PP 574.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. There is no definitive cure of it. Yet there are some options that reduce the symptoms of the disease. Which of the following medicine slowed the progression of the relapsing- remitting form of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Option b: Fingolimod is a receptor modulator drug. It has been shown to reduce relapse rates and slow the progression of relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS). Fingolimod is one of the more effective disease-modifying therapies for MS in terms of both relapse prevention and progression.
  • Option a: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used for acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis. It reduces inflammation and provides symptom relief during relapses, but it does not slow the progression of the disease. It is not a disease-modifying therapy.
  • Option c: Gamma interferons are not useful in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Instead interferon-beta can reduce relapse rates and has some effect on slowing the progression of the disease.
  • Option d: As option b is true d is not correct choice.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.238

Topic: Nerve fibers

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and a history of weight loss despite an increased appetite. On examination, she is found to be dehydrated, with dry mucous membranes and rapid breathing. Laboratory tests show a random blood glucose level of 450 mg/dL, and urine analysis shows glucose but no ketones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type 1 diabetes would typically present with ketosis or a more rapid onset of symptoms.

Option B: Type 2 diabetes mellitus can present with hyperglycemia, polyuria, and polydipsia without ketosis, especially in the absence of an acute metabolic crisis.

Option C: Diabetic ketoacidosis presents with ketosis and an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is absent in this case.

Option D: Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state is less common in young women and more common in older individuals with type 2 diabetes, but it is a possibility.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with hyperglycemia and dehydration without ketosis.

REFERENCE: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Chapter 404, page 3115

questions.text: A patient presented with hypo-pigmented macules over back and upper trunk, on KOH mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance was seen. What can be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Pityriasis versicolor. Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

Clinical lesions are hypo or hyperpigmented macules over neck, chest upper back.

Scratch sign- positive

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'

On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Treatment: Azoles, selenium sulphide 

Option A: Trichophyton sp. Causes dermatophyte injection- Tinea cruris, Tinea corporis, Onychomycosis.

Option D: Hortaea werneckii is causative agent of tinea nigra.

Option B: Candida sp causes intertrigo, oral candidiasis, Onychomycosis

Key takeaway:

Pityriasis versicolor

  • Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur
  • Clinical lesions are hypo or hyperpigmented macules over neck, chest upper back.
  • Scratch sign- positive
  • On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'
  • On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition,pg no 32.10

questions.text: The height of 100 students follows approximately normal distribution curve. The mean being 40.57 inch and median 40.79 inch. Calculate mode in this distribution?
questions.solution:
• In normal distribution curve, mean, median and mode coincide.
  • But if the distribution is not normal, the mean, median and mode will vary.
  • In near normal distribution curve, mode can be calculated from mean and median value.
  • The formula being Mode= 3xmedian - 2xmean.
  • Putting the values, mode will be 41.23.

Reference: Indranil Saha essentials of biostatistics and research methodology 4th/e page no: 53.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding. Endometrial biopsy reveals hyperplasia with atypia. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
In postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the risk of progression to endometrial cancer is high. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Cyclic progestins:

  • Progestins can be used to manage simple or complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • However, for hyperplasia with atypia, they are less effective in preventing progression to endometrial carcinoma.

B) Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD):

  • The LNG-IUD is effective in cases of hyperplasia without atypia or for patients desiring fertility preservation.
  • In postmenopausal women or cases with atypia, definitive surgical management is preferred due to the high risk of progression to cancer.

C) Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (Correct Answer):

  • The presence of atypia on biopsy significantly increases the risk of coexistent or progression to endometrial carcinoma (up to 40%).
  • Surgical removal of the uterus and ovaries is the definitive treatment and eliminates the risk of malignancy.

D) Endometrial ablation:

  • This is not suitable for managing hyperplasia with atypia, as it does not allow for histopathological evaluation of the endometrium.
  • It also does not treat the underlying condition effectively in high-risk cases.

Key takeaway:

  • Endometrial hyperplasia Without atypia:
    • Risk of malignancy<5%
    • Management: progesterone (antiproliferative,stabilises endometrium] - oral, IUD. [mirena], injectable.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia / Endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia
    • Risk of malignancy 25-33%
    • Definitive management:- Total abdominal Hysterectomy [ TAH]

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 149: Endometrial Hyperplasia. Obstetrics & Gynecology. 2015.

choices.text: Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, brain
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, heart, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood and urine

questions.text: The materials to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning during an autopsy include:
questions.solution:
Viscera to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning include; stomach and proximal 30 cm of small intestine with their contents, 500 gms liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood (25 ml) and urine sample.

Special viscera (To be preserved along with routine viscera):

  • Brain is also to be preserved in cases of volatile and other CNS poisons.
  • Spinal cord should be preserved in case of strychnine and gelsemium poisoning.
  • Half of each lungs or one whole lung should be preserved in case of inhaled poisons.
  • Entire heart should be preserved in cases of cardiac poisoning, arsenic poisoning, etc.
  • Bones, and scalp hairs are preserved in heavy metal poisoning.
  • Nails can be preserved in arsenic poisoning.

A saturated salt solution is used commonly for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Rectified spirit is indicated for most of the poisons, exceptions being alcohol, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, carbolic acid, acetic acid, etc.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 91

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with complaints of dysphagia and chest discomfort. High-resolution Manometry was done which showed IRP >31mmhg, 100 % failed peristalsis, and> 40% PEP. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Type1: elevated median IRP (>15mmHg), 100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mm Hg/s/cm)

Type2: elevated Median IRP (>15mmHg), panesophageal pressurization (PEP) ≥20% of swallows

Type3: elevated median IRP (>15mmHg), premature contraction ≥20% swallows with DCI >450mmHg/s/cm


Key takeaway points:

CCv4.0 no longer distinguishes between major versus minor motility disorders but simply separates disorders of EGJ outflow from disorders of peristalsis.

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed, page no: 1122

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with history of fever, abdominal distention and pain abdomen for 4 weeks. USG abdomen showed moderate ascites and altered echotexture of liver. U do diagnostic paracentesis to look for etiology of ascites. Total protein is 5.8g/dL, Serum albumin is 2.8 g/dL and ascitic fluid protein is 2.2g/dL, AF albumin -2.0, Total cells 200/μL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SAAG= Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

SAAG ≥1.1g/dL suggest Portal Hypertension related ascites whereas SAAG <1.1g/dl suggests non-portal hypertension related ascites.

SAAG in this case is 0.8g/dl- Ascites not due to portal Hypertension.

OPTIONS A, B, C- Causes of high SAAG ascites ≥1.1g/dL

OPTION D- TB is a cause of low SAAG ascites.

KEY TAKEAWAY:


Reference: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 50 PAGE 323

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-month history of a growing, ulcerated lesion on his forehead. He has a history of end-stage renal disease and underwent a kidney transplant 5 years ago. Since then, he has been on immunosuppressive therapy with cyclosporine, azathioprine, and prednisone. Physical Examination:
On examination, the patient has a 2 cm x 3 cm ulcerated lesion on his forehead, with rolled edges and a friable base. The lesion is tender to touch and bleeds easily. Which type of skin cancer is associated with an increased risk in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that is more aggressive than SCC, but it is not as strongly associated with organ transplantation.

B) Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is also a type of skin cancer, but it is less common in organ transplant recipients than SCC.

C) Patients who have had organ transplants are at increased risk of developing skin cancers, particularly Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC). This is due to the immunosuppressive therapy required to prevent rejection of the transplanted organ.

Immunosuppression increases the risk of skin cancer by:

  1. Reducing the immune system's ability to repair DNA damage caused by UV radiation.
  2. Allowing human papillomavirus (HPV) to persist and promote tumor growth.
    • SCC is the most common type of skin cancer in organ transplant recipients, and it tends to be more aggressive and prone to metastasis than SCC in the general population.

D) Merkel Cell Carcinoma is a rare type of skin cancer that is not typically associated with organ transplantation.

Key takeaways:

Organ transplant recipients are at increased risk of developing Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) due to immunosuppressive therapy.

choices.text: Tumour markers need to be measured before orchidectomy
The most useful means of detecting metastases to the chest is X-ray chest
The mean serum half-lives of AFP and HCG are 5-7 days and 2-3 days, respectively
LDH is less specific for testis cancer than HCG or AFP

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about testicular tumors?
questions.solution:
Option A: Blood is taken before orchidectomy to measure the levels of tumor markers, which are raised in around 50% of cases. A rise in AFP is seen in around 50-70% of NSGCTs and a rise in HCG is seen in 40-60% of NSGCTs and around 30% of seminomas.

Option B: While a chest radiograph can show the 'classical' cannonball metastase. CT scanning of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis has taken over as the most useful means of detecting metastases and monitoring the response to therapy. Hence option B is incorrect

Option c: The mean serum half-lives of AFP and HCG are 5-7 days and 2-3 days, respectively

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is expressed on chromosome 12p, which is often amplified in testis cancer cells. LDH is less specific for testis cancer than HCG or AFP. However, elevated LDH levels are associated with high tumor burden in seminoma and recurrence in NSGCT.

Key Takeaway Point:


Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed, Page no: 1571

questions.text: A 5-year-old was admitted to PICU for altered mental status and suspected meningitis. The child presents with generalized tonic clonic seizures since last 1 hour. You promptly administer benzodiazepines, fluids, and ceftriaxone and vancomycin. Despite anticonvulsants, the seizure persists. Which complication of meningitis is most likely to cause a seizure that is refractory to the above treatments?
questions.solution:
• Hyponatremia from the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH (SIADH) is a common complication of bacterial meningitis.
  • Hyponatremic seizures are notoriously resistant to anticonvulsants and need to be treated with appropriate saline solutions.
  • A brain abscess (choice A) is a complication that may cause seizures, but usually is not one of the presenting signs. This complication may need neurosurgical care.
  • Again, subdural empyema (choice B) is not a presenting sign, but seizures resulting from irritation from an empyema usually respond well to therapy.
  • Increased ICP (choice D) is a possible complication from meningitis and may cause seizures (but not as common as hyponatremia).

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA edition, pg no: 2944

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with acute weakness and confusion. Serum sodium is 118 mEq/L. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
OPTION A- Fluid restriction is appropriate for chronic or mild hyponatremia but not for acute severe cases.

OPTION B- Hypertonic saline infusion is the treatment of choice for severe symptomatic hyponatremia to prevent cerebral edema.

OPTION C- Oral salt tablets are used in chronic hyponatremia but are not suitable for acute management.

OPTION D- Normal saline may worsen hyponatremia in patients with SIADH due to increased free water retention.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures or confusion) warrants cautious correction using 3% hypertonic saline.
  2. Avoid rapid correction to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome-target an increase of no more than 6-8 mEq/L in 24 hours.
  3. Identify and treat the underlying cause (e.g., SIADH, adrenal insufficiency).

REFERENCE: HARRISON'S PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION CHAPTER 53 PAGE 342

choices.text: It identifies the presence of mycobacterial DNA in the specimen
It detects the species of nontuberculous mycobacteria
It differentiates M. tuberculosis complex from non-tuberculous mycobacteria
It helps detect drug resistance in M. tuberculosis isolates

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of MPT64 antigen detection in the identification of M. tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• (A) It identifies the presence of mycobacterial DNA in the specimen:This is not the primary function of MPT64. It is an antigen detection test, not a DNA detection method.
  • (B) It detects the species of nontuberculous mycobacteria:This is incorrect. MPT64 is specific to the tuberculosis complex, not NTM.
  • (C) It differentiates tuberculosis complex from non-tuberculous mycobacteria: This is correct. MPT64 antigen is specific to M. tuberculosis, M. bovis, and M. africanum and is used to differentiate them from NTM.
  • (D) It helps detect drug resistance in tuberculosisisolates: This is incorrect. MPT64 antigen detection is not used for drug resistance testing.

Reference: Apurba sastry, 3rd ed CHAPTER - 65 PP 743.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, and discomfort during urination. On examination, there is erythema of the vaginal mucosa, and a "strawberry cervix" is noted. Which of the following is the most sensitive diagnostic method for trichomoniasis?
questions.solution:
• OPTION C: Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing trichomoniasis. It detects the genetic material of Trichomonas vaginalis with high accuracy.
  • OPTION A: Wet mount microscopy can identify motile trichomonas but has low sensitivity (~50-70%).
  • OPTION B: Culture is more sensitive than wet mount but less commonly used due to longer turnaround time.
  • OPTION D: Gram stain is not a reliable method for diagnosing trichomoniasis as vaginalis is not easily visualized.

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 3, Gynaecologic Infection, Page no: 63

questions.text: Mikulicz cells and Russel bodies are the histological features of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition of the nose and other structures of the upper respiratory tract. Rhinoscleroma is a result of infection by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

The cytological features include a lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate admixed with classical Mikulicz cells. Histopathologic analysis has a definite role in the diagnosis of rhinoscleroma.

Classic histopathologic findings include large vacuolated Mikulicz cells and transformed plasma cells with Russell bodies. The Mikulicz cell is a large macrophage with clear cytoplasm that contains the bacilli; this cell is specific to the lesions in Rhinoscleroma.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 183.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, 5 days postpartum, presents with severe mood swings, irritability, and disturbed sleep. She expresses feelings of hopelessness, and her family reports that she has withdrawn from social interactions. She denies any history of psychiatric illness. On examination, she is tearful and shows significant anxiety.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum depression (A): This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms of severe mood swings, irritability, disturbed sleep, feelings of hopelessness, and social withdrawal. The onset within the first few weeks postpartum is characteristic of postpartum depression, which is often marked by depressive symptoms like sadness, anxiety, and loss of interest, without psychotic features. It affects 10-15% of women after childbirth.
  • Postpartum psychosis (B): Although this condition can present with mood swings and irritability, it is more severe and includes psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions, which are not present in this case. Postpartum psychosis usually occurs within the first 2 weeks postpartum and requires urgent psychiatric intervention.
  • Adjustment disorder (C): This condition occurs in response to a stressful life event, but it usually does not cause the severity of symptoms seen here, such as significant mood disturbances and hopelessness. Adjustment disorder is typically less severe than postpartum depression and does not usually involve prolonged depressive symptoms.
  • Bipolar disorder (D): Bipolar disorder involves alternating periods of depression and mania. While this patient has depressive symptoms, there is no evidence of a manic or hypomanic episode, which would be required for a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. Furthermore, the onset is related to the postpartum period, making postpartum depression more likely.

Reference: American Psychiatric Association. Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5).

questions.text: 50-year-old man has had headache, dizziness, and fatigue for the past 3 months. His friends have been commenting about his increasingly ruddy complexion. He also has experienced generalized and severe pruritus, particularly when showering. He notes that his stools are dark. On physical examination, he is afebrile, and his blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg. There is no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. CBC shows hemoglobin, 22.3 g/dL; hematocrit, 67.1%; MCV, 94 μm3; platelet count, 453,000/mm3; and WBC count, 7800/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) typically presents with leukocytosis (high WBC count) and often with hepatosplenomegaly.

B) Erythroleukemia typically is not accompanied by such a high hematocrit concentration because leukemic erythroid progenitors do not differentiate into mature RBCs.

C) Essential thrombocytosis is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that primarily affects platelets, but it does not typically cause polycythemia.

D) This patient has polycythemia vera (PCV), a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by an increased RBC mass, with hematocrit concentrations typically exceeding 60%.

  • Although the increased RBC mass is responsible for most of the symptoms and signs, these patients also have thrombocytosis and granulocytosis. This occurs because, similar to other myeloproliferative disorders, PCV results from transformation of a multipotent stem cell.
  • The high hematocrit concentration causes an increase in blood volume and distention of blood vessels.
  • The neoplastic erythroid progenitor cells require extremely small amounts of erythropoietin for survival and proliferation; the levels of erythropoietin are virtually undetectable in PCV.
  • When combined with abnormal platelet function, this condition predisposes the patient to bleeding. Abnormal platelet function also can predispose to thrombosis.
  • The pruritus and peptic ulceration most likely are the result of the histamine release from basophils.
  • Positive stool sample for occult blood, which suggests gastrointestinal bleeding, possibly due to increased blood viscosity.
  • Elevated platelet count (453,000/mm3), which is also consistent with PV.

Key Takeaway:

Definition / general

  • BCR: ABL1 negative myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) characterized by peripheral erythrocytosis frequently accompanied by leukocytosis or thrombocytosis

Essential features

  • Relatively common MPN characterized by increased red blood cell (RBC) production with elevated red blood cell count and hemoglobin level, which is not proportional to erythropoietin (EPO) production (usually has markedly decreased EPO level)
  • JAK2V617F (exon 14, valine to phenylalanine) and JAK2 exon 12 mutations are identified in > 95% and ~5% of patients, respectively.
  • Occurs in 3 phases
    • Prodromal / prepolycythemic
    • Overt polycythemic
    • Postpolycythemic myelofibrosis / spent
  • < 20% undergo blastic transformation within 15 years

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 624.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and excessive nausea and vomiting for the past month. She is 10 weeks pregnant according to her last menstrual period. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a "snowstorm" pattern with no identifiable fetus. Serum beta-hCG levels are markedly elevated for gestational age. What is the definitive diagnostic tool for confirming gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

A) Serum beta-hCG levels:

  • Elevated beta-hCG levels strongly suggest GTD, but they are not definitive for diagnosing the type or confirming GTD. They are primarily used for screening and follow-up.

B) Pelvic ultrasound:

  • A "snowstorm" pattern on ultrasound is highly suggestive of GTD, particularly a complete hydatidiform mole. However, ultrasound cannot confirm the type of trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Snowstorm appearance.

C) Histopathological examination of uterine contents (Correct Answer):

  • This is the gold standard for diagnosing GTD.
  • It allows confirmation of the type of trophoblastic proliferation (e.g., complete mole, partial mole, or malignant GTD).

D) MRI of the pelvis:

  • MRI can evaluate the extent of GTD, especially in suspected invasive or metastatic cases, but it is not used for definitive diagnosis.

Reference: FIGO Oncology Committee. Gestational Trophoblastic Disease Guidelines, 2015.

questions.text: Enzyme Deficiency seen in Maple Syrup Urine Disease is
questions.solution:
Maple Syrup Urine Disease is autosomal recessive disorder in which there is partial or complete deficiency of Branched Chain Alpha Keto dehydrogenase enzyme. This enzyme is involved in metabolism of Leucine, Isoleucine and valine aminoacids.

Due to deficiency of this enzyme, above branched chain amino acid and their corresponding Keto acid accumulates in blood causing toxic effect to brain function.

Other symptoms including feeding Problem, Vomiting, Neurological Manifestation, ketoacidosis, change in muscle tone and coma.

Increased excretion of isoleucine in urine give rise to Maple Syrup like odor of the Urine. So it is called as Maple Syrup urine disease.

Other Options

Option A) Phenylalanine hydroxylase require for conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria. Most common inborn error of metabolism. Clinical Presentation includes elevated level of phenylketones in urine, Intellectual Disability, Developmental delay, Microcephaly, seizures, Hypopigmentation.

Option B) Cystathionine Synthase deficiency leads to homocystinuria. Accumulation of Homocysteine occurs in urine. Methionine and Homocysteine is elevated in blood. Cysteine is low. Clinical Signs includes skeletal deformities, clotting, lens dislocation, intellectual disability.

Option D) Methylmalonyl co A mutase deficiency leads to Methylmalonic Acidemia. Elevated level of Methylmalonic acid in blood. Metabolic Acidosis and developmental problems are seen.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Biochemistry SAE Chapter 25, Page no: 404-406

choices.text: Administer a second dose of calcium gluconate

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with severe preeclampsia is receiving intravenous magnesium sulfate therapy. During routine monitoring, she develops labored breathing and hypotension. Her deep tendon reflexes are absent, and her serum magnesium level is found to be 12 mEq/L. Despite administering calcium gluconate, her respiratory symptoms persist. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
A) Initiate mechanical ventilation

  • Although respiratory support may be required temporarily, this does not address the underlying toxicity caused by elevated magnesium levels.

B) Perform hemodialysis

  • Severe magnesium toxicity with levels >12 mEq/L often requires hemodialysis, especially when symptoms persist despite calcium gluconate administration. Hemodialysis is the most effective method for rapid removal of excess magnesium from the body.

C) Administer a second dose of calcium gluconate

  • Calcium gluconate is an antidote to counteract the effects of magnesium toxicity, but repeated doses are unlikely to resolve symptoms if magnesium levels remain critically high.

D) Increase fluid administration

  • Increasing fluids may help promote renal excretion of magnesium but is insufficient in severe cases where levels are dangerously elevated and symptoms persist.

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 222: Gestational Hypertension and Preeclampsia. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2020.

choices.text: Erythematous edematous and eroded gingival and buccal mucosa
Bilateral barely palpable painless subcutaneous nodules adjacent to olecranon process
Dermatomal linear streaks or plaques of upper or lower extremities
Hypertrophic, erythematous pinkish lesions overlying dorsal interphalangeal joints

questions.text: A 12-year-old female with a history of fever, weight loss, and arthralgia is noted on physical examination to have proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory findings include elevated levels of serum creatinine kinase, an elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer, and a negative anti-double stranded DNA. Which of the following is most likely to be identified during physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has clinical and laboratory manifestations of juvenile dermatomyositis. Hypertrophic, erythematous, pinkish lesions overlying the dorsal interphalangeal joints are known as Gottron papules and are considered a pathognomonic sign of the disorder.
  • Additional clinical manifestations may include:
    • Edematous, erythematous, bluish eyelids (heliotrope rash of the periorbital area)
    • Periorbital, cheek, and knee variegated telangiectasia
    • Periungual telangiectasia and cuticular hypertrophy
    • Dry, scaling scalp
    • Cutaneous calcinosis
  • Patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have proximal muscle weakness and may thus complain of difficulty brushing their teeth, combing their hair, climbing stairs, or standing from a sitting position.
  • Inflammatory changes may also affect the muscles of the gastrointestinal tract (causing constipation), the upper airway (causing dysphonia and dysphagia), and the heart (causing arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy).
  • Elevation of one or more muscle enzymes occurs in nearly every patient.
  • Patients usually have a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and negative rumatoid factor (RF); up to 60% of patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have elevated ANA titers, whereas more specific tests for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), such as anti-double-stranded DNA, are negative.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1281

questions.text: Histological features of papillary carcinoma of thyroid includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) has several histological features, including:

Branching papillae: These are made up of a central fibrovascular core and a lining of cuboidal to columnar cells.

Follicles: Tumor cells may form follicles that contain colloid.

Squamous metaplasia: Foci of squamous metaplasia are often found.

Orphan annie-eye nuclei: The presence of these nuclei is a significant feature for diagnosing PTC.

Ground glass appearance: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Nuclear grooving: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Nuclear crowding: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Dusty chromatin: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Pale chromatin: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Intranuclear inclusion bodies: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

Mitotic figures: This is a histopathological feature of PTC.

PTC is the most common thyroid malignancy, accounting for 50% to 89% of cases. It usually appears as a firm, irregular mass that is not encapsulated.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg no: 384.

choices.text: Carotid sinus stimulation causing prolonged asystole
To prevent reflex-mediated hypotension in vasovagal syncope

questions.text:
A 69-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a syncopal episode while standing in crowded areas. He reports several similar episodes over the past year, triggered by prolonged standing or emotional distress.
Patient is diagnosed with severe neurogenic syncope.
Which of the following is primary indication for electrogenic pacemaker use in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Option a: In cardioinhibitory neurogenic syncope, with sinus pauses exceeding 4-6 seconds, Pacemaker implantation prevents bradycardia/asystole episodes, improving symptoms and quality of life. It is the correct option.
  • Option b: While pacemakers do not directly prevent hypotension in vasovagal syncope, their role in severe cardioinhibitory responses, like prolonged asystole, is well-documented. Reflex-mediated hypotension is not the primary issue here.
  • Option c: Baroreceptor dysfunction is not the primary pathology here. The problem is the excessive cardioinhibitory reflex leading to prolonged asystole.
  • Option d: As option a is the correct choice, this option does not fit as right choice.

Topic: Blood pressure

Topic: cardiac cycle

Topic: Electrocardiography

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no: 1200-1201

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is seen in the office for evaluation of bloody discharge from her left ear. It was difficult to visualize the left tympanic membrane because of the impacted wax. An ear curette was used to remove the cerumen and subsequently a normal left tympanic membrane was seen. After the visit, her mother noted blood coming from the left ear. The girl's vital signs are normal. Her physical examination findings are normal except for crusted blood in her left ear canal obscuring the tympanic membrane. Of the following the next best step is?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette should be given supportive care.
  • Irrigation could further irritate the ear canal and exacerbate the bleeding. (Option B)
  • Antibiotic ear drops are not needed at this time because an infection has not been identified. (Option C)
  • Referral to an otolaryngologist is also unnecessary because she has a simple superficial irritation that will resolve. (option D)
  • Bloody otorrhea that results from superficial irritation of the ear canal requires only reassurance and supportive care.
  • Counseling patients on appropriate ear hygiene can prevent ear canal irritation.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed, pg no: 3435

questions.text: Germ Cells do not senesce because of
questions.solution:
Germ Cell, Stem cell and Cancer cells, telomeres do not shorten and the cells do not senesce. This is a result of the ribonucleoprotein telomerase which maintain telomeric length in these cells.

Eukaryotic cells during Replication process, removal of the RNA primer from the extreme 5' end of the lagging strand, there is no way to fill the remaining gap with DNA. Most normal human somatic cells, telomeres shorten with each successive cell division. Once telomere shorten beyond some cirtical length the cell is no longer to divide and is said to be senescent.

Telomerase contain a protein that acts as a reverse transcriptase and short piece of RNA tat acts as a template.

Option A) Presence of Ribonucleoprotein Endonuclease: This refers to enzymes involved in RNA processing and is unrelated to telomere maintenance.

Option B) Absence of Telomerase: The absence of telomerase leads to telomere shortening and senescence, which does not occur in germ cells.

Option D) Presence of Polymerase A: DNA polymerase α is involved in DNA replication but does not maintain telomeres.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 35, Page no: 602

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman at 7 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with heavy bleeding and cramping. Ultrasound reveals a non-viable intrauterine pregnancy with no fetal heart activity. She requests a medical termination of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
• A) Dilation and curettage (D&C)
    • D&C is a surgical method for terminating pregnancies, but it is typically used for cases of complete miscarriageor retained products of conception, not for early medical termination or missed miscarriage when the patient prefers a non-surgical approach. However, D&C is also an option in cases of heavy bleeding or incomplete abortion, but medical management is preferred for early gestational age.
  • B) Misoprostol alone
    • Misoprostol is a prostaglandin that induces uterine contractions and is used to expel pregnancy tissue. However, mifepristone followed by misoprostol is the more effective medical regimen, as mifepristone (a progesterone antagonist) enhances the action of misoprostol and is recommended for more reliable outcomes in medical abortion.
  • C) Methotrexate
    • Methotrexate is typically used in the management of ectopic pregnancy. It inhibits DNA synthesis and is not suitable for intrauterine pregnancies or missed abortions.
  • D) Mifepristone followed by misoprostol
    • This is the most appropriate option for a missed miscarriage. Mifepristone is administered first to block progesterone, which is necessary for maintaining the pregnancy, and then misoprostol is given to induce uterine contractions and expel the pregnancy. This combination is highly effective and is recommended for medical management of missed abortion in early pregnancy.

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 143: Medical Management of First-Trimester Abortion (2014)

questions.text: Which of the following organ in female reproductive system form from Mullerian duct?
questions.solution:
• Mullerian duct forms the internal genital organs in female.
  • Option b: The Müllerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) develop into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper portion of the vagina in females.
  • Option a: The ovaries develop from the genital ridge, not the Müllerian duct. The genital ridge gives rise to the gonads (testes in males, ovaries in females).
  • Option c: The clitoris forms from the genital tubercle, not the Müllerian duct.
  • Option d: The labia majora develops from the labioscrotal swellings, which are not derived from the Müllerian duct.

Topic: Female reproductive system

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no: 902-904

choices.text: It is a congenital melanocytic nevus
It typically presents as a small, flat, hyperpigmented lesion
It is often associated with underlying muscle or skeletal abnormalities
It commonly appears in females during adolescence

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Becker's nevus?
questions.solution:
Option A. It is a congenital melanocytic nevus.

  • Becker's nevus is usually acquired rather than congenital.

Option B. It typically presents as a small, flat, hyperpigmented lesion.

  • Becker's nevus usually appears as a larger, irregularly shaped, hyperpigmented patch, often with coarse hair.

Option C. It is often associated with underlying muscle or skeletal abnormalities.

  • Becker's nevus can be associated with abnormalities such as hypoplasia of the underlying muscle.

Option D. It commonly appears in females during adolescence.

  • Becker's nevus is more commonly seen in males and typically develops during puberty.

Key takeaway:

Becker's nevus is characterized by hyperpigmented skin, often with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis), and can appear anywhere on the body but is most commonly found on the upper body and arms. It is thought to be related to an increase in melanocyte activity and may also have associations with certain muscle or connective tissue abnormalities.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, pg no: 1956

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC. One day your friend brought his dead father to the hospital and told you that he died of myocardial infarction. He pressures you to issue the death certificate and you oblige filling up myocardial infarction as the cause of death. Later there were accusations about this death and it was found that this person died of organophosphorus poisoning. You could be tried in court under which BNS/IPC section
questions.solution:
The doctor could be tried under BNS Sec 234 (IPC 197). It deals with issuing or signing false certificates.

BNS Sec 2(6), (IPC 46) denotes the death of the human being, unless the contrary appears from the context. In simple words, the word "death" denotes the death of a human being unless the context suggests otherwise.

BNS Sec 271 (IPC 269) denotes a negligent act likely to spread infection or disease dangerous to life.

BNS Sec 241 (IPC 204) denotes the destruction of documents to prevent their production as evidence.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 55

questions.text: Which imaging technique is most commonly used to diagnose osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Imaging of Osteomyelitis

Radiographs

  • Acute Osteomyelitis:
    • Soft tissue swelling
    • Bone demineralization or regional osteopenia (≈2 weeks after infection)
  • Chronic Osteomyelitis:
    • Periosteal reaction
    • Cortical erosions
    • Bony lucency and sclerotic changes
    • Bony lysis around hardware and prosthetic joints
    • Sequestra: Dead bone nidus with surrounding granulation tissue
    • Involucrum: Periosteal new bone formation later

MRI

  • Best method to show early osteomyelitis and anatomic location
  • Penumbra sign:
    • Bright signal in surrounding bone
    • Darker abscess and sclerotic bone
  • Negative finding rules out osteomyelitis
  • Positive finding may overestimate the extent of the disease

Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography (FDG-PET)

  • Shows malignancies and infections (increased glycolysis)
  • Most sensitive test for chronic osteomyelitis
  • More specific than MRI or bone scan

Reference: J. Maheshwar's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 291

questions.text: Which of the following medications is NOT used for opioid detoxification?
questions.solution:
Option A: Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is used for opioid detoxification and maintenance therapy.

Option B: Methadone: Methadone is also used for detoxification and maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder.

Option C: Naloxone: Naloxone is used to reverse opioid overdose, not for detoxification.

Option D: Clonidine: Clonidine is used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification.

Methadone:

  • Gold standard for treating opioid use disorder with physical dependence.
  • Used for detoxification and as a maintenance agent.
  • Dose typically starts at 20-30 mg, adjusted as needed, with a tapering schedule after stabilization.

Buprenorphine:

  • Partial opioid agonist that activates the receptor partially.
  • High affinity for receptors; may cause precipitated withdrawal if used with other opioids.
  • Used for detoxification and maintenance therapy; available as monotherapy or in combination with naloxone to prevent misuse.
  • Typically administered under medical supervision to avoid withdrawal.

Opioid Antagonists (Naloxone, Naltrexone):

  • Block opioid receptors without activation.
  • Naloxone: Used for overdose reversal; short-acting, may require repeated doses.
  • Naltrexone: Long-acting, used post-detoxification to prevent relapse by blocking opioid effects.

Overdose Treatment:

  • Prioritize airway management and mechanical ventilation.
  • Naloxone is given intravenously to reverse overdose; dose may be repeated if no improvement is seen.
  • Naloxone may need repeated doses due to its shorter duration compared to opioids.

Methadone and Buprenorphine in Detoxification:

  • Methadone: Initial dose is 20-30 mg, increased if needed, followed by gradual tapering. Used in inpatient and outpatient settings.
  • Buprenorphine: First dose given when withdrawal symptoms are moderate, then titrated. Used for both detoxification and maintenance.

Nonopioid Medications for Withdrawal:

  • Clonidine for autonomic symptoms (e.g., sweating, restlessness).
  • Benzodiazepines for anxiety/agitation (inpatient).
  • NSAIDs for musculoskeletal pain, loperamide for diarrhea.

Opioid Substitution Therapy:

  • Methadone and buprenorphine reduce heroin use and related risks, allowing stable life.
  • Major drawback: ongoing opioid dependence.

Buprenorphine/Naloxone Combination:

  • Buprenorphine is a partial agonist with a ceiling effect, reducing overdose risk.
  • Naloxone reduces misuse risk by precipitating withdrawal if abused.

Opioid Antagonists:

  • Block opioid effects without causing dependence (e.g., Naloxone, Naltrexone).
  • Naltrexone is used post-detoxification to prevent relapse but has no mechanism to ensure continuous use.

References: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 4, Pages 947

questions.text: What is the method of administration of fluid through non compressible veins of the body called?
questions.solution:
Intraosseous fluid administration. Infusion of fluids though a metal cannula into the bone marrow and thence, via a system of non-collapsible veins, into the general circulation. Used in emergencies when intravenous access is not readily available. Previously reserved for the resuscitation of infants and children; adult needles and insertion devices are now also routinely available. The upper tibia (anteromedial surface 1-3 cm below the tibial tuberosity) and proximal humerus are the most common sites chosen. A manual needle and trocar kit may be used to pierce the thin bony cortex, advancement continuing until a loss of resistance is felt. Alternatively, a battery-powered drill may be used. Easy injection of saline without obvious subcutaneous infiltration suggests correct placement. Aspiration of marrow is not always possible, but if successful, samples can be used for cross-matching. All standard drugs may be given by this route; they should be flushed through with 5-10 ml saline to ensure they reach the circulation. Fluids should be given under pressure to overcome venous resistance. Osteomyelitis is the major complication and can be minimised by sterile technique and by reverting to conventional venous cannulation following resuscitation. Compartment syndrome has been reported.

Reference: Anaesthesia and Intensive care A-Z, Page 318.

questions.text: Under vitamin A prophylaxis program, how many megadoses of Vitamin A is advised?
questions.solution:
• According to Vitamin A prophylaxis program, children between 9 months and 5 years of age are given 9 megadoses of vitamin A concentrates at 6 months interval.
  • The first 2 doses are integrated with measles vaccination and DPT1 booster.

Reference: Nutrition and child development, KE Elizabeth, 5th ed., pg. 112

choices.text: Minimally Invasive Dynamic Coronary Arterial Bypass
Minimally Invasive Distal Coronary Artery Bypass
Minimally Invasive Dual Coronary Artery Bypass
Minimally Invasive Direct Coronary Artery Bypass

questions.text: What does the abbreviation MIDCAB stand for in cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
Minimally invasive direct coronary artery bypass (MIDCAB) grafting is performed through a small incision and avoids the invasive aspects of conventional CABG.

Key Takeaway Point:
Through an anterior submammary incision, the LIMA [left internal mammary artery] can be dissected using a thoracoscope and grafted to the LAD[ left anterior descending coronary artery].

More lateral incisions allow access to other coronary vessels, including branches of the circumflex artery. Although not yet evidence-based, one approach is to combine MIDCAB (typically LIMA to LAD) with PCI to other less accessible coronary arteries ('hybrid' coronary revascularization).

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 953

choices.text: Contact wound of the head due to small caliber weapon
Lacerated wound of the head due to a knife with a hilt
Distant shot of the head with a small caliber weapon
Contact wound of the head due to large caliber weapon

questions.text: Blowback phenomenon is most likely to be seen in
questions.solution:
Blowback phenomenon is seen in contact shot and a contact wound of the head from a large caliber weapon is more likely to produce back spatter than a wound of the trunk from a small-caliber weapon.

Gunshot contact wounds and also close range discharges may cause blood and tissue fragments to enter the muzzle, sometimes penetrating for several centimeters, due to negative pressure created following the discharge and is known as Back spatter. The presence of back spatter is dependent on both anatomical site that is injured and the weapon used.

Sometimes blood and tissue may soil the hand or arm of the person firing the gun, a matter of considerable significance in forensic science.

Reference: Forensic Pathology Reviews- Volume 5, Page no. 158

questions.text: Para-amino hippuric acid when passing through kidney, it does not go through which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is a compound often used in renal physiology studies to measure renal plasma flow because it is handled in a specific way by the kidneys.
  • Option b: PAH is not reabsorbed after it enters the renal tubule.

Significance: This lack of reabsorption ensures that PAH remains in the tubular fluid after filtration and secretion, which makes it ideal for measuring renal plasma flow.

  • Option a: PAH is freely filtered by the glomeruli, meaning it passes from the blood in the glomerular capillaries into Bowman's space without restriction.
  • Option c: PAH is actively secreted into the renal tubules from the peritubular capillaries, primarily in the proximal tubule.

Significance: Nearly all PAH that is not filtered by the glomeruli is secreted into the tubules, ensuring its near-complete clearance from the plasma.

  • Option d: The term "excretion" refers to the final removal of a substance in the urine. Since PAH is neither reabsorbed nor metabolized, all the PAH filtered and secreted is excreted in the urine.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1545

Topic: Nephron - Excretory system

questions.text: The small particles around 2-5 micrometer in diameter are removed by which of the following actions of lung defence system?
questions.solution:
• Option a: Particles in the size range of 2-5 micrometers are typically removed by the mucociliary escalator as they escape upper airway defense.

This defense mechanism is present in the trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles. It consists of ciliated epithelial cells that beat in a coordinated manner to transport mucus, along with trapped particles, upwards toward the pharynx, where it can be swallowed or expelled.

  • Option b: Nasal hair acts as a coarse filter in the nasal cavity, trapping larger particles (greater than 30 to 50 micrometers) before they enter the respiratory tract.

While effective for larger debris, nasal hair does not capture smaller particles

  • Option c: The mucous membrane of the pharynx helps trap particles and microbes in mucus (5 to 10 micrometer).

However, this defense is more effective for particles that are carried upward by the mucociliary escalator or those deposited in the upper airways.

  • Option d: While each of the mechanisms mentioned contributes to respiratory defense, mucociliary escalation is the primary mechanism for removing particles of 2-5 micrometers in diameter.

Nasal hair and the mucous membrane of the pharynx are less effective for particles of this size.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1415 & 1419

Topic: Respiratory tract anatomy and functions

questions.text: Health communication is very important aspect from public health point of view because of the various functions it has. All of the following are functions of health communication except?
questions.solution:
• Health communication has to cater to the following needs: -
  • Information: - The primary function of Health Communication is to provide scientific knowledge or information to provide about health problems and how to maintain and promote health.
  • Education: - Education of the general public as an integral part of the prevention-oriented approach to health and disease problems and the basis of all education is communication.
  • Motivation: - It is a power that drives a person from within to act. One of the goals of Health Communication is to motivate individuals to translate health information into personal behaviour and lifestyle for their own health.
  • Persuasion: - The sole purpose of communication is to influence. Persuasion is a conscious attempt by one individual to change on influence the general beliefs, understanding, values and behaviour of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way.
  • Counselling: - Counselling is a process that can help people understand better and deal with their problems and communicate better with those with whom they are emotionally involved.
  • Raising morale: - Morale is the capacity of a group of people to pull together persistently or consistently. Communication vertical and horizontal internal and external is the first step in any attempt to raise morale of the health team or a group of people.
  • Health development: - Communication can play a powerful role in health development by helping to defuse knowledge in respect of the goals of development and preparing the people for the roles expected of them.
  • Health organisation: - Communication is the life and blood of an organisation. There are two major directions in which communications within an organisation flow, these are vertical and horizontal communications.

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th/e page no.984,985.

questions.text: A slow-activity isozyme of which enzyme is most likely responsible for an individual to exhibit a very low tolerance to alcohol, leading to the individual rarely drinking?
questions.solution:
Alcohol consumption results in increased adverse reactions to acetaldehyde owing to a genetic defect of mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase in some asian population.

An isozyme of ALDH has a dramatically increased Km (>200-fold) and a 1 0-fold reduced Vmax·

In such individuals, acetaldehyde, the toxic component of alcohol ingestion, accumulates to a large extent, leading to the individual having a very low tolerance for alcohol.

A slow-acting ADH would not lead to a low tolerance to alcohol because acetaldehyde accumulation (the toxic intermediate of alcohol metabolism) would be slowed such that the acetaldehyde produced can be safely metabolized without any side effects.

Acetate, once produced, is not toxic, so a slow-acting acetyl-CoA synthetase (which uses acetate as a substrate) would not lead to the accumulation of a toxic intermediate. MEOS is used as an alternative ethanol-oxidizing system when ethanol levels are high.

A slow-acting MEOS would reduce the production of acetaldehyde, which is the toxic intermediate of alcohol metabolism. This would not lead to a low level of tolerance to alcohol.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is not involved in ethanol metabolism (the acetyl-CoA formed would be used for energy). Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is needed for fatty acid synthesis, and if its activity were low, fatty acid production would be reduced, but it would have no effect on the tolerance to alcohol

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 25 Page 255

choices.text: Severe IgE mediated cow milk protein allergy

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to MMR vaccine?
questions.solution:
• MMR is contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals- low steroid does not decrease immunity.
  • Low fever is not a contraindication
  • It does not contain egg protein
  • Gelatin or small amount of milk protein is present, hence contraindicated in those with severe type of IgE mediated milk protein allergy.

Reference: IAP guidebook on Immunization, 3rd ed., pg. 227

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a person with a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes.
questions.solution:
Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a complete or partial absence of melanin, leading to a lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes. Individuals with albinism often have very light skin and hair, and they may also experience vision problems due to the lack of pigment in the eyes.

Option A. Vitiligo: This condition involves the loss of skin pigmentation in patches, but it does not affect the entire body uniformly as seen in albinism.


Option C. Piebaldism: This is a genetic condition that presents with white patches of skin and hair, but it usually involves some areas of normal pigmentation and does not affect the eyes.


Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This is a genetic disorder that causes benign tumors in multiple organs and may lead to skin findings such as hypopigmented macules, but it does not result in the generalized lack of pigmentation seen in albinism.


Key Takeaway

Albinism is a genetic condition marked by a complete or partial absence of melanin, resulting in a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes, often accompanied by vision problems.

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition. Pg no- 70.6

choices.text: A sense of lack of control over eating during binge episodes.
Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviours (e.g., vomiting, misuse of laxatives).
Disturbance in body shape and weight perception.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is unique to Bulimia Nervosa compared to Anorexia Nervosa?
questions.solution:
Option A: Both disorders involve a fear of weight gain, but it's a defining characteristic of Anorexia Nervosa.

Option B: Both disorders have a sense of loss of control during eating episodes, but this behaviour is tied more to Bulimia Nervosa, where the eating episodes are followed by compensatory actions.

Option C: In Bulimia Nervosa, compensatory behaviours like vomiting or using laxatives are key diagnostic criteria.

Option D: This is common to both Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa.

Anorexia Nervosa (AN):

  • Criterion A: Significant weight loss due to restriction of energy intake, resulting in body weight significantly below normal for age, sex, and health.
  • Criterion B: Intense fear of weight gain or persistent behavior to prevent weight gain, even at low body weight.
  • Criterion C: Distorted body image or lack of recognition of the seriousness of low weight.
  • Subtypes:
    • Restricting type: Weight loss through dieting, fasting, or exercise.
    • Binge-eating/purging type: Involves binge eating or purging behaviours (vomiting, misuse of laxatives).

Bulimia Nervosa (BN):

  • Criterion A: Recurrent binge eating (large amounts of food with lack of control).
  • Criterion B: Inappropriate compensatory behaviours (vomiting, laxatives, excessive exercise).
  • Criterion C: Occurs at least once a week for 3 months.
  • Criterion D: Self-evaluation unduly influenced by body shape and weight.

Binge-Eating Disorder (BED):

  • Criterion A: Recurrent binge eating (large quantities of food with lack of control).
  • Criterion B: Three or more of the following:
    1. Eating rapidly.
    2. Eating until uncomfortably full.
    3. Eating large amounts when not hungry.
    4. Eating alone due to embarrassment.
    5. Feeling disgusted, depressed, or guilty afterward.
  • Criterion C: Distress about binge eating.

Night Eating Syndrome (NES):

  • Criterion: Recurrent episodes of eating after waking from sleep or after the evening meal, with awareness and recall.
  • Distress/impairment: Eating at night causes distress or functional impairment.
  • Not explained by: Other mental disorders, binge-eating disorder, or medical conditions.

References: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 13, Pages 1497

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is not seen in case of the complications of the portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Portocaval anastomosis:

  • There are many sites in the abdominal cavity where anastomosis exists between the portal and systemic venous systems.
  • These communications between the veins of the portal and caval (systemic) systems form important routes of collateral circulation in cases of portal obstruction.
  • The important sites of portocaval anastomoses are as follows:
  • Umbilicus:
    • Here the left branch of the portal vein communicates with the superficial veins of the anterior abdominal wall around umbilicus, through paraumbilical veins.
    • In portal obstruction, the superficial veins around the umbilicus become distended and tortuous (varicosity).
    • This whorl of prominent distended tortuous (snake-like) veins around the umbilicus is known as caput medusae.
  • Lower end of esophagus:
    • Here the esophageal tributaries of left gastric vein (draining into the portal vein) anastomose with esophageal tributaries of accessory hemiazygos vein (systemic).
    • In portal obstruction as in liver cirrhosis, these collateral channels become distended and tortuous, forming esophageal varices, which may rupture causing hematemesis (vomiting of blood) and may even bleed to death.
  • Anal canal:
    • Here the superior rectal (hemorrhoidal) vein which ultimately drains into the portal vein anastomoses with middle and inferior rectal veins, the tributaries of internal iliac (systemic) vein.
    • The distension and dilatation of these anastomotic channels result in the formation of hemorrhoids or piles which may be responsible for repeated bleeding (hematochezia) per annum.
  • Extraperitoneal surfaces of retroperitoneal organs:
    • Veins of retroperitoneal organs such as duodenum, ascending colon, and descending colon (portal) anastomose with the retroperitoneal veins of the posterior abdominal wall and renal capsule (systemic).
    • The renal vein anastomosis with splenic and azygos veins.
  • Bare area of liver:
    • Here the hepatic venules (portal) anastomose with phrenic and intercostal (systemic) veins.

Level: Must know

Topic: Porto-caval anastomosis

Key Points:

Portal hypertension:

  • Obstruction of the portal vein or its branches leads to the increase in the portal venous pressure called portal hypertension, i.e., pressure above 40 mmHg (normal being 5-15 mmHg).
  • This leads to enlargement of collateral channels.
  • The most common cause of portal hypertension is alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver.
  • The effects of portal hypertension are:
    • Caput medusae (distended tortuous veins around the umbilicus)
    • Splenomegaly (enlargement of the spleen)
    • Ascites (accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity)
    • Esophageal varices (hematemesis)
    • Hemorrhoids (hematochezia)

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition, Volume - 2, Page No - 130, 131, 132

choices.text: It is more commonly seen with solid organ transplants than with intestinal transplant
Treatment involves pulse steroid therapy with antiviral medications
The first-line treatment usually involves rituximab and immunosuppression reduction.
PTLD is usually associated with CMV viremia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding PTLD?
questions.solution:
PTLD[ post transplant lymphoproliferative disease ] is a potential complication of immunosuppression for any patient after a transplant.

Option C: If diagnosed with PTLD the first-line treatment is usually with rituximab and immunosuppression reduction. This has to be done with great caution in multivisceral/

intestinal transplant recipients because of the risk of rejection and the consequences thereof.

Option A: The incidence in intestinal transplant recipients is higher than for other solid organ transplant recipients - up to 17% in some series. This is likely to be due to both the level of immunosuppression and the amount of lymphoid tissue associated with an intestinal-containing graft.

Option B: Treatment in severe cases, involves reducing immunosuppression with or without antiviral medications.

Option D: PTLD should be considered if there is a persistent positive EBV viremia or B symptoms such as night sweats, unexplained fevers, and weight loss.

Key Takeaway Point:

Intestinal transplantation is the most challenging area of abdominal transplantation, with higher rates of complications than other transplant groups.

These complications include rejection, sepsis, post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD), and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed - Page 1635

choices.text: Primary bone healing occurs with the formation of a callus, while secondary healing involves direct contact between bone fragments without callus formation.
Secondary healing is characterized by the formation of a bone callus, whereas primary healing occurs with direct contact of the bone ends and no callus formation.
Primary healing involves significant soft tissue involvement, while secondary healing occurs without soft tissue involvement.
Both primary and secondary healing require the formation of a bone callus for the healing process to complete

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about primary and secondary healing of bone fractures?
questions.solution:
Primary and Secondary Healing of Bone Fractures

Primary Healing

  • Occurs when bone ends are in direct contact.
  • Typically achieved with rigid fixation, such as surgical plates or screws.
  • No callus formation is observed.
  • Requires precise alignment of the fracture site.
  • Healing is slower compared to secondary healing.

Secondary Healing

  • Involves the formation of a callus.
  • Happens when there is some movement at the fracture site.
  • The process begins with a soft callus that gradually hardens into bone.
  • Commonly occurs when fractures are not rigidly fixed.
  • Generally takes more time to complete compared to primary healing.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 11.

questions.text: Which of the following infections requires male partner treatment?
questions.solution:
• Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It is essential to treat all sexual partners to prevent reinfection and further spread of the disease.

Option A. Candida: This fungal infection can occur in individuals due to factors like diabetes or immunocompromised states, and does not typically necessitate partner treatment.

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not classified as an STI and does not require treatment of male partners.

Option D. Herpes: While herpes is a recurrent viral infection, it does not always require partner treatment, as recurrences can occur without new exposure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichomoniasis requires treatment for both partners to effectively manage and eliminate the infection.
  • Understanding the nature of each infection is crucial for appropriate management and prevention strategies.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no-33.36

questions.text: Which of the following nerve roots are primarily affected in Erb's palsy, a type of brachial plexus injury?
questions.solution:
Erb's palsy typically results from an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which involves the C5 and C6 nerve roots. This leads to weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by these roots, such as the deltoid, biceps, and brachialis, causing a characteristic "waiter's tip" deformity/ policeman's tip hand deformity (arm adducted, internally rotated, and pronated).

Erb's Palsy

  • Definition: Erb's Palsy is a neurological deficit involving injury to the C5 and C6 nerve roots of the brachial plexus, affecting the upper limb.
  • Causes:
    • Most commonly caused by excessive lateral traction or stretching of a baby’s head and neck during childbirth.
    • In adults, it can result from trauma involving forceful separation of the neck from the shoulder.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Affects nerves that control the deltoid, biceps, brachialis, and brachioradialis muscles, leading to paralysis or weakness in shoulder abduction, external rotation, elbow flexion, and forearm supination.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • "Policeman's Tip Deformity": Arm is adducted and internally rotated, elbow extended, forearm pronated, and wrist flexed.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical presentation, history of trauma or birth complications, and possibly imaging (X-rays, MRI).
  • Management:
    • Conservative: Physical therapy and exercises for mild cases.
    • Surgical: Nerve repair or transfer for severe cases not improving within 3-6 months.
  • Prognosis:
    • Depends on the severity; mild cases often recover fully, while severe cases may need surgical intervention.

Erb's Palsy requires timely diagnosis and management to optimize outcomes, especially in cases involving childbirth.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 25,64,74,368.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding interaction required for production of X-rays in X ray tube ?
questions.solution:
X-rays are produced when fast moving electrons are suddenly stopped by impact on a metal target. The electrons penetrate several micrometers into the target and lose their energy in two ways:

  1. Interaction with the outer electrons of the atoms producing heat (99%).
  2. Interaction with either the inner shells of the atoms, or the field of the nucleus (bremsstrahlung interaction) producing X-rays (1%).

Reference: Chirstensen's physics of diagnostic radiology, 4th edition, page no. 29.

questions.text: CPAP is a form of ventilation, that is
questions.solution:
An alternative to IPPV via tracheal tube, positive pressure ventilation may be applied via a tightly fitting nasal mask, facial mask, nasal 'pillows' that fit into the nostrils, or a 'helmet' that encloses the whole head. Ventilators may deliver a set volume or, more commonly, a set pressure.

BIPAP (bi-level positive airway pressure) refers to a technique in which two levels of positive pressure are provided during inspiration and expiration. Airflow in the patient circuit is sensed by a transducer and augmented with a pre-set level of positive pressure. Cycling between inspiratory and expiratory modes may be triggered by the patient's spontaneous breaths or according to a pre-set rate (cycling either fully automatically or only if the patient fails to take a spontaneous breath within a certain time period). CPAP may also be delivered in either mode. BIPAP may also be administered via an oral mask.

Reference: Anaesthesia and Intensive care A-Z, Page 414

questions.text: Which of the following is marker for contrast induced nephropathy (CIN)?
questions.solution:
Markers for contrast induced nephropathy includes:

  • Serum creatinine level
  • Estimated GFR - < 60ml/min/1.73 m2
  • Serum cystatin levels
  • Plasma neutrophil gelatinase associated lipocalin (NGAL)

Reference: HAGGA CT and MRI of whole body - Textbook of radiology, page no - 1755.

questions.text: What is the predominant pattern of lung injury seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on imaging studies?
questions.solution:
A) Ground-glass opacities: While these can be seen in IPF, honeycombing is more characteristic of advanced disease.

B) Honeycombing: This is correct. Honeycombing is a classic radiological finding in advanced IPF, indicating severe fibrosis and cystic changes in the lungs.

C) Consolidation: This pattern is more typical of pneumonia and is not characteristic of IPF.

D) Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is not a common feature of IPF and is often absent.

Key Takeaway:

The predominant imaging pattern in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, particularly in advanced cases, is honeycombing, reflecting severe fibrotic changes in the lung architecture.

  • Major findings are consistent with UIP pattern
  • Patchy dense fibrosis with architectural distortion
    • Lesion representing UIP pattern is mainly composed of hyalinized collagen
    • Often destructs alveolar architecture
    • Smooth muscle and elastofibrosis are often present
    • Only mild infiltration by inflammatory cells should be seen (usually near areas of honeycomb change)
    • Honeycombing: cystic spaces lined by bronchiolar epithelium and fibrotic wall
    • honeycomb change - cystic spaces lined by bronchiolar epithelium and fibrotic wall.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 689.

questions.text: The intravenous pain following administration of propofol can be mitigated by
questions.solution:
Pain on injection occurs in up to 28% of subjects. The incidence may be reduced by the addition of lidocaine (1 ml of 1%), cooling the drug, and the use of large veins.

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith 5th edition pg 326.

questions.text: Single bubble sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Single bubble sign -> pyloric stenosis.
  • Double bubble sign -> duodenal atresia
  • Triple bubble sign -> jejunal atresia
  • Multiple bubble sign -> ileal atresia

Reference: Grainger and Allison's - Textbook of diagnostic radiology, page no - 1826.
